div.l: When that april with his showres swote
The drouth of March hath ꝑperced the rote
And bathed euꝰery veyne in swich licour
Of which vertu engendred is the flour
When zepherus eke with his swete breth
Inspired hath in every holt and heth
The tendre Croppes and the yong sonne
Hath in the Ram his halfe cours y ronne
And smale fowles maken melodye
That slepeth al nyght with open ye
So pryketh hem nature in her corages
Than longen folk to gon on pilgrimages
And palmers to sechen strange strondes
To ferne halwes couth in sondry londes
And specialy from euꝰery shires ende
Of Engelond to Caunterbury they wende
The holy blisfull martir for to seke
That hem hath holpen when they were seke
Befel that in that sesoūn on a day
In Suthwerke at the taberd as y lay
And redy to wende on my pilgrimage
To Caunterbury with ful deuoute corage
At nyght was comen into that hostrye
Wel nye a twenty in a companye
Of sondry folk by aventure y falle
In felawship and pilgremes were they alle
That toward Caunterbury wold þei ryde
The chambres and stables weren wyde
And wel were esed at the beste
And shortly whan tyme was to reste
So had y spoken with ham euꝰerychone
That y was of here felawship anone
And made forwarde erly for to ryse
To take oure wey ther as y you deuyse
But natheles while y have tyme and space
Or that y further in this tale pace
Me thinketh it acordeth to resoūn
To tel you al the condicioūn
Of ech of ham so as it semed me
And which they were and of what degre
And eke in what aray þey were yn
And at aknyght than woll I furst by gyn
A knyght ther was and that a worthi man
That fro the tyme þat he first bygan
To ryden oute he loued chyualrye
Trouth and honour fredom and curtesye
For worthi was he in his lordes warre
And therto had he ryden no man ferre
As wel in Cristendome as in hethenesse
And euꝰer honoured for his worthinesse
At alisaundre he was whan it was y wonne
Ful ofte tyme he hadde the burde by gonne
Aboue al nacions in pruce
In lectow had he raised and in Ruce
No cristenman so ofte of his degre
In Garnade eke at the sege had he be
Of algezire and ryden in Belmarye
At lyeis was he and at Satalie
When they were wonne and in þe grete see
At many anobyl harme had he be
At mortal batayles had he be fyftyne
And foughten for oure feyth at tramyssene
In lystes thries and ay slayen his fo
This ilke worthi knyghtes had byn also
Som tyme with þe lorde of palatye
Ayein an other hethen in Turkye
And euꝰermore he had a sovereyne prys
And þough þat he was worthi he was wys
And of his porte as meke as a mayde
He never yit no vylonye seide
In al his lyfe vnto no manꝰer wyȝt
He was averray ꝑperfite gentle knyth
For to tellen you of his array
His hors was gode þough he was not gay
Of fustian he vere a Gypoūn
Al be smotered with his habergeou
For he was late ycome fro his viage
And wente forto do his pilgrimage
With hym þꝰer was his sone a yonge squyer
A louyer and a lusty bachiler
With lokkes crulle as þey were leyde in presse
Of twenty yere of age he was y gesse
Of his stature he was of even lenghte
And wanderly deliuer and grete of strenghte
And he hade byn som tyme in chiuachie
In flaundres in Arteys ⁊ pykardye
And boren hym wel as of so litel space
In hope to stonden in his lady grace
Embroyded was he as it were a mede
All full of fressch floures white and rede
Syngyng he was or floityng al þe daye
He was as fressch as is þe month of maye
Short was his gowne with sleves longe ⁊ wyde
Wel couth he sitte on hors and feyre ryde
He couth songes make and wel endyte
Iuste and eke daunce ⁊ wel portraye and wryte
So hote he loued that bye nyghtꝰer tale
He slept na more þan doth a nyghtyngale
Curteis he was lowly and seruysable
And carfe be fore his fader at þe table
A yheman had he and ꝸseruantes namo
At þat tyme for hym luste to ryde so
And he was clad in cote and hode of grene
A sheffe of pocokarewes bryght and kene
Vnder his belt he bare ful þriftyly
Wel couth he dresse his tacle yemanly
His arwes drowped not with fethers lowe
And in his honde he bare a myȝty bowe
A not hede had he with a broune vysage
Of wodecrafte wel couth he al þe vsage
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracere
And by his side a swerd and a bokelere
And on þat other side a gay dagger
Harneysed wel and sharp as poynt of spere
A Cristofer on his breste in seluer shene
An horne he bare þe bauderik was of grene
A forster was he sothly as y gesse
Ther was also a nonne a prioresse
That of her smylyng was ful simple and coye
Here grettest oth was but by seint loy
And sho was cleped madame eglentyne
Ful wel sho songe the ꝸseruice deuyne
Enteund in her note full semely
And frenssch sho spake ful feire and fetisly
After þe scole of stafford atte Bowe
For frenssch of parys was to hir vnknowe
At mete wel ytaught was sho with alle
Sho lette no morsel from hir lippis falle
Ne wette her fyngres in hir sauce depe
Wel couth sho cary a morsel and wel kepe
That no drop ne fylle vpon hir breste
In curtesye was sette ful mochel hir liste
Hir over lippe wiped sho so clene
That in hir coppe was no ferthyng a sene
Of grece when sho dronken hadde hir draught
Ful semely after hir mete sho raught
And sekerly sho was of grete disporte
And ful plesant and amyable of porte
And peyned hir tocōmtꝰerfete chere
Of Court and to ben estatelich of manere
And to be holden digne of Reuerence
But for to speken of hir conscience
Sho was so charitable ⁊ so pitous
Sho wolde wepe if þat sho saw a mous
Caught in a trappe if it were dede or bledde
Of smale houndes had sho that sho fedde
With rosted flessch or mylke and wastelbrede
But sore wepte sho if oon of hem were dede
Or yf men smote it with a yerde smert
And al was conscience and tendre hert
Full semely hir wympul pynched was
Hir nose tretys hir yen grey as glas
Hir mouth ful smale and therto softe ⁊ rede
But sekyrly sho hadde a feyre forehede
Hit was almost A sponne brode y trowe
For herdelye sho was not vnder growe
Ful fetys was hir cloke as y was war
Of smale Coral abowte hir arme sho bar
A peyre of bedy y gauded al with grene
And the on hynge a broch of golde full shene
On which was first wreten with a crowned A
And after Amor vincit omnia
A other nonne with hir hed sho
That was hir Chapeleyne ⁊ preste thre
Amonk ther was a feire for þe maistre
And outerider that loued venerie
Amanly man to byn an abbat able
Ful mony a deynte hors had he in stable
And when he rode men myȝt his brydel here
Gynglyng in a whistelyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doth þe chapell belle
Ther as this lorde was keper of þe selle
The rule of seint Maure or of seynt Benette
Be cause that it was olde and somdel streyt
This ilke monke lete olde thinges pace
And hilde after the newe worlde þe space
He yaf nought of þe texte a pulled hen
That seith that honters be not holy men
Ne that A monk whan he is rechelesse
Is likened tyl afyssch that is waterlesse
This is to seyn a monk oute of his cloystre
But thilke texte he hilde nought worth an oystre
And y seyde his opineoūn was gode
What shulde he studye and make hym selue wode
Vpon a boke in Cloystre al wey to powre
Or swynke with his hondys and laboure
As austyn byt how shal þe worlde be ꝸserued
Let austyn have his swynk to hym reꝸserued
Ther fore he was a prikasoure a ryght
Greyhoundes he hadde as swyfte as fowle in flyȝt
Of prikyng and of huntyng for þe hare
Was al his lust for no coste wolde he spare
I sigh his sleves y pulfyled at þe honde
With gryce and that þe fynest of alonde
And forto festen his hode vnder the chyn
He had of golde wrought a ful curyous pyn
A love knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His hede was balled that shone lyke any glas
And eke his face as it hed ben anoynted
He was a lord ful fat and in gode poynt
His yen stepe and rollyng in his hede
That semed as asas a forneys of lede
His botys souple his hors in grete estate
Now certeynly he was a feyre prelate
He nas nat pale as forpyned gost /
A fat swan loued he best of eny rost
His palfray was as broun as is a bery
A frere ther was a wantan and a mery
A lymyter a ful solempne man
In al þe orders fowre is non that can
So mochel of daliaunce and feir langage
He hed made ful mony a maryagemaryage
Of yonge wymmēm at his owne cost
Vnto his ordre he was a noble post
Ful welbeloued and famylier was he
With frankelens oueral in his contre
And with worthi wemen of þe towne
For he had power of confessione
And seide hym selfe more than a Curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Full swetly harde he confessiou
And plesant was his absolucou
He was an esy man to yeuen penaunce
Ther as he wist to have a gode pitaunce
For vnto apore ordre forto yeve
Is signe that a man is well yshryve
For yf he yafe he durst make avaunt
He wist that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so hard is of his herte
He may nought wepe al þough hym sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng and preyers
Men mote yeve seluer to the pore frerys
His tepet was aye forsed ful of knyues
And pynnes for to yeven feyre wyues
And certeyly he had a mery note
Wel couth he synge ⁊ pleyen on a rote
Of yeddynges he bare vtterly þe prys
His nek white was as þe flour delys
Therto he stronge was as A Champyoūn
He knowe the tavernys wel in every toun
And everich hosteler and tapestere
Bet than a lazer or a beggestere
For vnto suche a worthi man as he
Acorded noȝt as by his faculte
To have with such lazers acqueyntanse
It is not honeste it may nought auaunce
For to delen with such poraille
But al with rich and celers of vitaille
And ouer al ther as profit may a ryse
Curteys he was and ful of ꝸseruise
Ther nas no man nowhere so vertuous
He was þe best begger in his hous
For though a widdowe hadde noȝt a sho
Soplesaunt was his Inprincipio
Yet wolde he have a ferthing yer he wente
His purchase was wel better þan his rente
And rage he couth ryght as it were a wehlpe
In lovedayes ther couth he moch helpe
For ther he was noȝt like a Cloistrere
With a thridbare cope as is a pore scolere
But he was like a maistꝰer or a pope
Of dowble worstede was his semycope
That rounde rourounderounde as a belle out of þe presse
Somwhat he lypsed for his wantaunesse
To make his englissch swete vpon his tong
And in his harpyng whan he had y song
His yen twynkled in is hede a right
As don þe storrys in the frosty nyght
This worthi lymyter was called huberd
A Marchaunt was þer with a forked berd
In motle and high on hors he satte
Vpon his hede a flaundryssch bever hatte
His botys clapsed feyre and fetuoslye
His resons he spake full solempnelye
Shewyng alwey thencrece of hys wynnyng
He wolde þe see were kepte for eny thyng
By twyx myddelborgh and Orwell
Wel couth he in eschange sheldys selle
This worthi man ful wel his wit by sette
Ther wist no wight that he was in dette
So estately was he of his governaunce
With his bargaynes and with his cheuessaunce
Forsoth he was a worthi man with all
But soth to seyn y not how men hym call
A Clerk ther was of Oxenford alsoo
That vnto logyk had longe y goo
As lene was is hors as is A rake
And he nas nat right fat y vndertake
But loked holowe and therto soberly
Ful thredbare was his ouereste curtebye
For he hadde geten hem yet no benefyse
Ne was so worldly for to haue office
For hym was lever have at his beddeshede
Twenty bokys clad in blak and rede
Of aristotle and his filozofye
Than robes rich or fethel or gay sawtrye
But al be that he was a philesophre
Yet hadde he but lytel golde in Cofre
But al that he myght of his frendes hente
On bokys and on lernyng he it spente
And besy gan for the sowlys prey
Of hem that yaf hym wherwith to scolay
Of studye toke he most cure and most hede
Naught a worde spake he more þān was nede
And that was seide informe and reverence
⁊ short and quyk and ful of high sentence
Sownyng in moral matyr was hys spech
And gladly wolde he lerne and gladly tech
A sergeant of the lawe war and wys
That often hed be at pervys
Ther was also ful rich of excellence
Discrete he was and of grete reverence
He semed such his wordes were so wyse
Iustice he was ful often in assise
By patent and by playn cōmmissiou
For his science and for is high renoun
Of fees and robes hadde he many oon
So grete a purchaser was nowher noon
Al was fee simple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myȝt noght benbenebene ffecteinffecteinffecte
No wher so besy aman as he ther nas
And yet he semed besier þan he was
In termys hedde he caas and domus alle
That fro þe tyme of kyng william were falle
Ther to he couth endite ⁊ and make a þyng
Ther couth no wight pynch at is writyng
And every statute couth he plepleynpleyn by rote
He rode but homely in amedle cote
Gyrt with a seint of silk with barrys smale
Of his aray tel y no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his companye
White was his berde as is þe daysye
Of his complexiou he was sangwyne
Wel loued he by þe morow a sop in wyne
To leuen in delyte was euꝰer his wone
For he was Epiours owne sone
That helde opinion that pleyn delyte
Was werray felicite ꝑperfyte
An housholder and that agrete was he
Sint Iulian he was in his contre
His brede his ale was al weyes after oon
A better envyned man was neuer non
With outen bakemete was neuꝰer his hous
Of flessch and fyssch and that so plentyuous
Hit snwed in his hous of mete and drynk
Of al dentes that men couth thynk
Aftꝰer þe sondry sesou of þe yere
So clanged he his mete ⁊ his sopere
Ful mony a fatte ꝑpertrych had he in muwe
And mony abreme ⁊ mony a luys in stuwe
Wo was his coke but yf his sawce were
Poynant and sharp and redy all his gere
His table dormant in his halle alwey
Stode redy covered al þe longe day
At sessions ther was he lorde and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of þe shire
An anlas and a gipser all of syesylkesykle
Hyng at his gyrdel white as morne mylke
A Shireve had he be and comptour
Was nowher such a worthi vauasoure
And haberdasscher and A Carpentere
A webbe a dyer and a tapicere
And þei were clothed al in on lyuere
Of a solempne and and a grete fratꝰernite
Ful fressch and new her gere a pyked was
Here knyues nere chaped noȝt with bras
But al with siluer wrought ful clene and welle
Hir girdellys and her pouches euꝰerydelle
Wel semed ich of hem a feire burgeis
To sitten in a yeldhall on a deys
Euerich for þe wysdom þat he kan
Was shaply for to byn an alderman
For catell hadde þei y nough and rent
And eke here wyfes wolde it wel asent
And elles certeyn þei were to blame
It is ful feire to byn ycleped madame
And gon to vigilles alle be forn
And have a mantell ryallich y born
A cook þei hedde with hem al for þe nonys
To byle þe chiknes with þe marybonys
And powdre marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wel coude he knowe a draught of londou ale
He couth rost ⁊ seth and boyle and frye
Maken mortroux and wel bake a pye
But grete harme was it as it þought me
That on his shyne a mormall had he
For blankmanger þat made he with þe beste
A Shipman was þer wonnyng fer by weste
For ought y wote he was of dertemouth
He rode vpon a Rouncy as he couth
In a gowne of faldyng to þe kne
A dagger hangyng in a lace had hee
A bowte his nekke vnder his arme downe
The hote somer had made his hewe al browne
And certeynly he was a gode felawe
Ful mony a draught of wyn hadde he drawe
Fro Burdeaux ward while þe chapmen slepe
Of nyce concience toke he no kepe
Yf þat he faught and hadde þe higher honde
By water he sent hem home to euꝰery londe
But of his crafte to ryken wel his tydes
His stremys and his dangers hym besides
His herberwe and his mone and his lodmanage
Ther was non such from hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was and wys to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berde be shake
He knew al þe havyns as þey were
Fro Skotlond to þe Cape defynystre
And euery cryk in brytayne and in spayne
His barge y cleped was þe mawdeleye
With ous þer was a doctour of Phisik
In alle this worlde ne was þꝰer non hym lyke
To speke of phisik and of surgerye
For he was grounded in astronomye
He kept his paciens a ful grete dell
In hourys by his magik naturell
Wel couth he fortune ascendent
Of his ymage for his pacient
He knewe the cause of euerych maladye
Were it of hote or colde or moistre or drye
And wher engendred and []ofofwhat humoure
He was a verray ꝑperfit practisoure
The cause y know and of his harme þe rote
A non he yaf þe sike man his bote
Ful redy hadde he his appottekaries
To sende hym drogges and his letuarys
For ech of hem made other for to wynne
Her frendship nas nat new to bygynne
Wel knewe he þe holde Esculapius
And discorides and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras haly and galien
Sarapioūn Razis and auyzen
Auerois damascien and Constantyne
Bernard and Gatesden and Gylbertyne
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑperfluyte
But of grete norissyng and digestible
His study was but lytyl on þe bibylle
In sangwyne and pers he clad was alle
Lyned with taffata and with sendall
And yet he was but esy of dispense
He kept þat he wan in pestelence
For gold in phisik acordyal
Ther fore he loued golde []īnīn especial
A gode wife ther was of beside bathe
But sho was somdel def and þat was scathe
Of cloth makyng sho hadde such anhaunte
Sho passed hem of yprys and of Gaunte
In al þe parissch wyf þen was ther noon
That to the offryng by fore hir shulde gon
And yf ther dede certeyne wroth was she
That she was oute of all clarite
Hire couerchifs ful fyne were of grounde
I durst swere they weyden ten pounde
That on a sonday were vpon here hede
Hir hosy were of fyne skarlet Rede
Ful streyte y tyed and shoes ful moiste ⁊ newe
Bolde was hir face and feir and rede of hewe
Sho was a worthi womman al here lyue
Housbondes at churchdore had she fyue
Withouten other company in youth
But þerof nedeth noȝt to speke as nouth
And thries hadde sho byn at Ierusaleme
She had passed many a strange streme
At Rome she had byn and at boloyne
In Galice at seint Iame and at Coloyne
She couth much of wandryng by the way
Bad tothed was she sothly for to sey
Vpon an ambuler esily she satte
Y wympled wel and on hir hede an hatte
As brode as as bokker or a targe
A hote mantell a bowte hir hippys large
And on hir fete a peir of sporys sharpe
In felawship wel couth she laugtlaugthelaugthēm ⁊ carpe
Of remedies of loue she knewe ꝑperchaunce
For she knew of that art þe olde daunce
A gode man was ther of religiou
And was a pore parson of a town
But Riche he was of holy þought and werke
He was also alerned man a Clerk
That cristis gospel trewlych wold preche
His parisschons deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was and wonder deligent
And in aduercite full pacient
And swich he was preued ofte sithes

l.seg: Ful loth were hym to cursyn for hys tithes

div.l: But rather wold he yeven owte of dowte
Vnto his pouer parisshons a boute
Of his offryng and of his sustenaunce
He couth in litel þyng haue suffisaūnce
Wide was his parisch an houses fer a sondre
But he ne lafte for rayne ne for thundre
In sikenesse nor in myschif to visite
The firrest in his parysh moch and lite
Vpon his fete and in his honde a staf
This noble ensample to his sheep he yaf
That first he wroȝt and afterward þat he tauȝt
Out of þe gospel he the wordes cauȝt
And this figure he hadded eke ther to
That if gold rust what shal yren do
For if a prest befoule on whom we truste
No wonder is a lewde man to ruste
And shame it is if a prist take kepe
A shiten shiphurd and a clene shepe
Wel ought a prist emsample for to yeve
By his clennes how that is shepe shuld lyve
He sette noȝt his benefice to hyre
And lete his shepe be accōmbered in the myre
And ran to london vnto seint powlys
To seken hym a chaunterye for soulys
Or with a bretherhede to be with holde
But dwelled at home and kept wel his folde
So that þe wolf made it noȝt myscarye
He was a sheperd and noȝt a mercenarye
And þough he holy were and vertuous
He was noȝt to symful men dispituous
Ne of his spech dangerous ne digne
But in his teching discrete and benygne
To drawen folk to heven by fayrnesse
By gode ensample this was his bisinesse
But it were eny ꝑpersone obstinate
What so he were of high or lowe estate
He wolde hym snyppen for þe nonys
A bettꝰer pꝰerste y trou þat nowher noon es
He waited after no pompe and reverence
Ne maked hym aspiced concience
But cristes lore and his apostelys twelue
He tauȝt but first he folowed in hem selue
With hym ther was a plowman þtat was his broþer
That hadde iladde of donge ful mony a fother
A trew swynker and a gode was he
Levyng in pees and ꝑperfite cherite
God loued he best with al his hert
At al tymes þought he gamed and smerte
And than his neghboure right as hym selue
He wolde throsshe and therto dyke and delue
For cristes sake every pore wyȝt
With oute hire yf it lay in his myȝt
His tithes payed he ful feir and well
Both of his ꝓpropre swynk and his catell
In ataberd he rode vpon a Mare
Ther was also a reve and a Millere
A somnour and a pardoner alsoo
A Mansiple and my selfe þꝰer were no moo
The myller was a stowte carle for þe nonys
Ful bigge he was of brawne and of bonys
That ꝓproued wel oueral where he cam
At wrastelyng he wolde have awey the ram
He []waswas short shuldert a thikke knarre
Ther was no dor that he wolde heve of barre
Or breke it at the rennyng with his hede
His berde as eny sowe or fox was rede
And therto brode as þough hit were a spade
Vpon the coppe right of his nose he hadde
A wert and þꝰeron stode a tufte of herys
Rede as the bristyls of a sowys erys
His nose thrillys blak were and wyde
A swerd and a bokeler bare he by his syde
His mouth as grete was as a furneys
He was a Iangeler and a Golyardeys
And that was most of synne in harlotryes
Wel couth he stele corne and tolle thryes
And yet he hed a thombe of golde ꝑperde
A white cote and a blewe hode wered he
A bagpype wel couth he blow and sowne
And ther with al vs broȝt oute of toune
A gentle Manciple was ther of a temple
Of which achatours myȝt take ensample
For to ben wyse in bryngyng of vitaile
For whether that he toke or payed by taile
Algate he wayted so in his achate
That he was ay beforn and in gode estate
Now is nauȝt þat of godde a ful feir grace
That such alewdeman ys witte shal passe
The wysedom of anhepe of lerned men
Of maistres had he mo þan þryes ten
That were of lawe exꝑperte and curious
Of which ther was a dozeyn in that hous
Worthi to byn stewardes of rent and lond
Of eny lorde þat is in Ingelond
To make hym leve by his ꝓproꝑpere gode
In honoure dettles but yef he were wode
Or lyve as skarsly as hym list desire
Al able to helpen al a shire
In eny cas that myȝt falle or happe
And yet þis manciple sette hir alder cappe
The reve was a slender coleryk man
His berd was shave as ny as euꝰer he kan
His here was by his yerys ful rownde y shorne
His toppe was dokked lyke a prest be forne
Ful longe were his legges and ful lene
Like a staf þꝰer was no calf y sene
Wel couth he kepe a Garnar and a byn
Ther was non auditour couth of hym wyn
Wel wist he by the drowth and by þe reyne
The yeldyng of his sede and of his greyn
His lordes shepe his nete his dayerye
His swyne his hors his store and his pultrye
Was holy in þis reves gouernyng
And by his couenawnt yaf the rykenynge
Syn that his lorde was twenty yere of age
Ther couth no man bryng hym in arerage
Ther nas baillif ne herd nor oþꝰer hyne
That he ne knewe his sleytht in his covyne
They were a drad of hym as of þe deth
Hys wonyng was ful faire vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwed was his place
He couth better than his lorde purchace
Ful rych he was a stored pryvely
His lerd he couth wel plesen subtily
To yeve and lene of his owne gode
And have a thank and yet a cote and hode
In yowth he hadde lerned a gode misterye
He was a wel gode wryght of carpentrye
This reve sat vpon aful gode stot
That was al pomly grey an high scot
A longe surcote of pers vpon he hadde
And by his syde he bare a rusty bladde
Of northfolk was þis reve of which y telle
Byside a towne men clepith Baldeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere abowte
And ever he rode the hyndrest of oure rowte
A Somonour was þer with vs in that place
That hadde a feire cherubyns face
For sawseflevme he was with yen narowe
Als hote he was and lecherows as a sparowe
With scaled browes blac and pyled berd
Of his visage children were a ferde
Ther nas quyk sylver litarge nor brymstone
Boras cesure ne oyle of tartre noon
Ne oyment that wolde clense and byte
That hym myȝt helpen of his welkys white
Nor of the knobbys syttyng on his chekys
Wel loued he garlyc oynons and eke lekys
And for to drynke stronge wyn rede as blode
Than wolde he iangle as he were wode
A fewe termys hedde he two or thre
That he hadde lerned oute of somme decre
No worder is he harde it al the day
And eke ye knowen wel how that a Iay
Kan speke watte as wel as kan the pope
But who so couthe in other thinges hym grope
Than hadde he spende al his philosophye
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crye
He was a gentile harlot and a kynde
A better felaw shulde men nouȝt fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyn
A gode felawe to have his concubyn
A twelue monthe and excuse hym atte fulle
Ful preuely a fynch eke couth he pulle
And yf he founde owher a gode felawe
He wolde techen hym to have non awe
In suche cas of the archedeknes curs
But if mannys soule were in his pours
For in his purs he shulde y punysshed be
Pours is the Archedeknes helle seid he
But wel y wote he lyed right in dede
Of cursyng owght eche gulty man drede
For curs wol sle right as assoillyng saveth
And also ware hym a significauit
In daunger hadde he atte his owne gyse
The yonge girles of the diocise
And knew her counsel and was al here rede
A garland hedde he sett vpon his hede
As grete as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made hym of a kake
With hym ther rode a genthe ꝑperdoner
Of Rouncyvale his frende and his compar
That streight was comyn fro the court of Rome
Ful lowde he songe come heder loue to me bone
This somner bar to hym a styf burdoūn
Was never trompe of halfe so grete a soun
This pardoner hed here as yelewe as wax
But smothe alsoalso it hyng as doth a stryke of flax
By houncis hyng his lokkes that he hadde
And þer with he his shuldrys over sprarde
But thynne it lay by culpons oon and oon
But hode for Iolyte wered he noon
For it was trussed vp in his walette
Hym thought he rode al of the newe Iette
Discheuele save his cappe he rode al bare
Such glaryng yen hedde he as an hare
A vernicle hadde he sowed on his cappe
His walette by fore hym in his lappe
Brett ful of pardon come from Rome alle hote
A voice he hath as smale as it were a gote
No berde hedde he no never shulde have
As smothe it was as it were late yshave
I trowe he were a gildyng or a mare
But of his crafte fro berwyke in to ware
Ne was ther such a nother ꝑperdonere
For in his male he hedde a pilowe bere
Which that he seide was oure lady veile
He seide he hadde a gobet of the seile
That seint petre hadde whan that he wente
Vpon the see tille ihu criste hym hente
He hedde a croys of latyn ful of stones
And in aglas he hedde pyggys bonys
But with these Relikes whan that he fownde
A pore parson dwellyng vpon londe
Vpon a day he gate hym more moneye
Than that the ꝑperson gate in monthes tweye
And thus with feyned flatery and Iapys
He made the ꝑperson and the pore peple his apys
But trewly to tellen atte laste
He was in church a nobil eclesiaste
Wel cowth he rede a lessou or a story
But alderbest he songe an offretory
For wel he wist whan that songe was songe
He most preche and wel a fille his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel couthe
Ther fore he songe þe meryerly a louth
Now have y tolde you sothly in a clause
The estate þe array þe nombre ⁊ eke þe cause
Whi that assemeled was þe companye
In suthwerke at þis gentle hostrye
That hight the taberd fast by the belle
But now is tyme to you forto telle
How that we beren vs þat ilke nyght
Whan we were in that hostry a light
And after wolle y telle of oure viage
And all the remanante of oure pilgrimage
But first y prey you of youre curtesye
That ye ne recte it naught my vilanye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To telle you her wordes and her chere
Ne thogh y speke hir wordys ꝓproprely
For this ye knowen also wel as y
Who so shal telle a tale after a man
He mote reherce as nygh as ever he kan
Everich a worde if it be in his charge
Al speke he never so rudely ne so large
Or elles he mote telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thinges or fynden wordes newe
He may noȝt spare al thogh he were his brother
He mot als wel sey o word as a nother
Crist spake hym selfe ful brode in holy writte
And wel ye wot no vylanye is it
Eke plato seith who so can hym rede
The wordes mote be cosyn to the dede
Also y prey you foryeve it me
Alle have I notte sette folk in here degre
Here in þis tale as þat þei shulde stonde
My witte is short ye may wel vnderstonde
Grete chere made houre ooste vs everychone
And to the soper sette he vs a noon
He served vs with vitailles at þe beste
Stronge was þe wyn and wel dronk vs leste
A semely man oure oost was with alle
For to byn a Marchal of an halle
A large man he was with yen stepe
A feirer burgeys is noon in chepe
Bolde of his spech as wyse ⁊ wel ytaught
As of manhode hym lakked ryght naught
Eke þerto he was right a mery man
And after soper pleyn he bygan
And spake of myrth a mong oþer þinges
When þat we hed made oure rekenynges
And seid þus now lordynges trewly
Ye byn to me right welcom hertely
For by my trouth if shal not lye
Y sigh noȝt þis yere so mery a companye
At onys in this herberewe as is now
Fayn wold y don you myrth wist y how
And of a myrth y am right now nowith thoughtenow ith thoughte
To don you ese and it shal cost noughte
Ye gon to Caunterbery god you spede
The blisful marter quyte you yorur mede
And wel y wote as ye goon by þe wey
Ye shapen you to talen ⁊ to pley
For trewly comfort and myrth is noon
To ryden by þe wey dom as the ston
And þerfore wol y maken you disporte
As y seide arst and don you som comforte
And if you liked all by won assente
For to stonden at my Iuggemente
And for to wyrkyn as y shal you sey
To morow whan ye ride by þe wey
As by my fader soule þat is dede
But ye be mery y wol yeve you myn hede
Holde vp youre honde withoute more speche
Oure counsel was not longe for to seche
Vs þought it was not worth to make it wyse
And graunted hym withoute more avyse
And bade hym sei his veordre as hym leste
Lordyns qd he nou herkneth for þe beste
But take it noȝt I prey you in disdeyn
Þis is þe poynt to speke short and playn
That ich of you to short with oure weye
In this viage shal tellen tales tweye
To caunterburyward y mene it so
And homwardes he shal tellen oþꝰer two
Of aventurys þtat whilome have by falle
And which of you that bereth best of alle
That is to seyn þtat telleth in þis cas
Tales of best sentence and most solas
Shal have a soper at oure alder cost
Here in þis place sittyng by this post
Whan that we comyn a gayn fro caunterbury
And for to make you the more mery
I wol my silfe godly with you ryde
Right at myn owne coste and be youre gide
And who so wol my Iuggement withsay
Shal pay al þat we spende bi the way
And if ye vouchesave that it be so
Telle me a non withoute wordes mo
And y wol erly shapen me ther fore
This þyng was graunted and oure oþes swore
With ful gode hert and pꝰereyen hym also
That he wolde vouchsave for to so do
And that he wolde be oure governoure
And of oure tales Iugge and reportoure
And set a soper at a certeyn prys
And we wol ruled byn at his devys
In high and low and þus by on assent
We byn accordet to the Iuggement
And ther vpon þe wyn was fette anon
We dronken and to rest went echon
Withouten eny lenger taryeng
A morow whan þat day gan to spryng
Vp ros oure oost and was oure aldre cok
And gederid vs to geder in a flok
And forth we ryden a litel more þan pas
Vnto the watryng of seint thomas
And ther oure oost by gan is hors a rest
And seid lordynges herkeneth if you lest
Ye wote youre foreward and ek yorur recorde
If evensonge and morowe song accorde
Lat se now who shal telle þe first tale
As evere mote I drink wyn or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iuggement
Shal pay for al that by the wey is spent
Now draweth cut or that we ferther twynne
And which that hath þe shortest slal by gynne
Sir knyght qd he my maistꝰer and my lorde
Now draweth cut for that is myn acorde
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ye sir clerk let be youre shamefastnesse
Ne studieth naȝt ley honde to every man
A non to drawe euery wight began
And shortly to tellen as it was
Were it by aventure or sort or cas
The soth is this þe cut fel to þe knyȝt
Of which ful blithe and glad was euꝰery wyȝt
And telle he most his tale as it was reson
By forewar an by composicioūn
As ye have herde what nedeþ wordes mo
And whan þis gode man saugh þat it was so
As he that wyse was and obedient
To kepe his foreward by his fre assent
He seid senne y shal begynne the game
What welcome by the cut a goddes name
Now lete vs ryde and herkeneþ what y seye
And with þat worde we reden forth oure way
And by gan with right a mery chere
His tale a noon and seide as þe may here
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye

div.l: (base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure

div.l: (base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye

(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al

(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place

div.l: (base) That it made / al the gate for to rese

(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong

(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge

(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede

(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right

(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage

(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres

(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel

(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown

(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth

div.l: (base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet

(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here

(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked

div.l: (base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond

div.l: (base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon

(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun

(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold

(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace

(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old

div.l: (base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte

div.l: (base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some

(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree

(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste

(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge

(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne

(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was

(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron

div.l: (base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee

(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse

(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me

(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue

(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go

(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere

(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances

(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook

div.l: (base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf

div.l: (base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle
(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille
(base) Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf
(base) In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne short swerd for to stoke / with point bitynge
(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde
(base) But o cours / with a sharp ygrounde spere
(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon
(base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down
(base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
(base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede
(base) Out brest the blood / with sterne stremys rede
(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun
(base) And he hym hurteth / with his hors adoun
(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
(base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
(base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
(base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
(base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght
(base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
(base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
(base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
(base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye
(base) Ther may no man / clepe it cowardye
(base) ¶ For which anoon / duc Theseus leet crye
(base) To stynten / al rancour and enuye
(base) The gre / as wel of oo syde as of oother
(base) And eyther syde ylyk as otheres brother
(base) And yaf hem yiftes / after hir degree
(base) And fully heeld a feeste / dayes three
(base) And conueyed / the kynges worthily
(base) Out of his toun / a iournee largely
(base) And hoom wente euery man / the righte way
(base) Ther was namoore / but fare wel haue good day
(base) Of this bataille / I wol namoore endite
(base) But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) Swelleth the brest of Arcite / and the soore
(base) Encreeseth at his herte / moore and moore
(base) The clothered blood / for any lechecraft
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Corrupteth / and is in his bouk / ylaft
(base) That neyther veyne blood / ne ventusynge
(base) Ne drynke of herbes / may been his helpynge
(base) The vertu expulsyf / or animal
(base) Fro thilke vertu / clepyd natural
(base) Ne may the venym / voyden ne expelle
(base) The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
(base) And euery lacerte / in his brest adown
(base) Is shent with venym and corrupcioun
(base) Hym gayneth neither / for to gete his lyf
(base) Vomyt vpward / ne downward laxatyf
(base) Al is to brosten / thilke regioun
(base) Nature / hath no dominacioun

Ye most byn ful derne as in þis caas
