A clerk hed litherly by sette his while
But yf he coude a Carpenter by gile
And þus þey byn accorded and y sworne
To wayte atyme as I have tolde by forn
Whan Nicholas hedde done þis euery dell
And thakked hir a boute þe lyndes well
He kisseth hir swete and taketh his sawtry
And pleyeth fast and maketh molodye
Then fylle it þus þat to þe parissch chirch
Cristes owne werkes for to wurch
Þis gode wyfe went on an halyday
Hir forchede shone as bryȝt as eny day
So was it wesshen when she lefte warke
Now was þer of þat church a parissch clerke
The which þat was y cleped absolon
Crul was his her and as þe golde it shon
And stowtedstlowtedstlowted as a fane large and brode
Ful streight and even lay his Ioly shode
His rode was rede his yen grey as a gose
With poules wyndow corven on his shoos
In hosyn rede he went fetously
Y cladde he was ful smale and ꝓproprely
Al in a kirtel of alight wagette
Ful feyre and þikke byn þe poyntys sette
And ther vpon he hedde a feire surplys
As white as is þe blosom on þe rys
A mery child he was so god me save
Wol couth he letyn blood and clippe and shave
And make a chartre of londe or a quytaunce
In twenty maner coude he trippe and daunce
After þe scole of Oxenforde tho
And with his legges casten two ⁊ fro
And playen songes on a smale rubible
Ther to he song som tyme alowde quynyble
As wel coude he pley on a geterne
In al þe town was þe noþer noþerno brewhous ne taverne
Ther any gailerd tappester was
Þat he ne visited with his solas
But soth to seyn he was somdel squaymous
Of fartyng and of speche daungerous
Þis absolon þat Ioly was and gay
Goth with a censer on þe holy day
Censyng þe wives of þe parissch fast
And namely alovely loke on hem he cast
And namely on þe Carpenterys wife
To loke on hir him þought a mery lyfe
She was so ꝓpropre and swete and lycorous
I dar wel sey yf sho hedde byn a Mous
And he a Cat he wolde hir hente A nōmn
Þis parissch clerk þis absolou
Hath in his hert suche a love longyng
Þat of no wif toke he non offeryng
For curtesie he seide he wolde noūn
Þe mone whan it was nyȝt ful bright shoun
And absolon his giterne hedde y take
For ꝑperamourys he þought for to wake
And forth he goth iolyf and amarous
Tyl he cam to þe Carpenters hous
A litel after Cokkys hedde y crowe
And dressed him vp by a shot wyndowe
Þat was vpon þe Carpenters walle
He syngith in his voys gentille and smalle
Now dere lady if þi wylle be
I prey you þat ye wol rewe on me
Ful wel accordant to his giternynge
Þis Carpenter a wooke and herde him synge
And spake vnto his wyfe and seyde anon
What alison herestow not absolon
Þat chaunteþ þis vnder oure bowres wal
And she answered hir housbonde ther with al
Þis god wot Iohn y here it euery dell
Þis passeth forth what wolle ye bette þan welle
Fro day to day þis Ioly absolou
So woweth hir þat he is woo by gou
He waketh al þe nyȝt and al þe day
He kembeþ his lokkes and make hem gay
He woweth her by menes and brokage
And swore he wolde byn hir owne page
He syngeth brokkyng as a nyȝtyngale
He sent hir piment Meth and spiced ale
And wafres piping hote oute of þe glede
And for she was of town he ꝓprofered mede
For somme folke wol be wenwowenwowen for richesse
And sōmme for stōmkes and sōmme for gentillesse
Sōmme tyme to shew his lyȝtnesse and maistrye
He playeth herawdes vpon a skaffold hye
But what a vayleth him al in þis caas
She leueth so þis hynde Nicholas
Þat absolon may blowe þe bukkys horn
He ne hedde for his laboure but a squorn
And þus sho makeþ absolon her ape
And al his ernest turneth til a Iape
Ful soth is þis ꝓproverbe it is no lye
Men seyn alwey righ þus þe nygh slye
Maketh þe ferre lef to be loth
For þough that absolon be wood or wroth
By cause þat he ferre was fro hir syȝt
Þis nye Nicholas stode in his lyght
Now bere þe wel þou hende Nicholas
For absolon may wayle ⁊ syng allas
And so by felle it on a seterday
Þis Carpenter was gon to Oseney
And hende Nicholas and alison
Accorded byn to þis conclusioūn
Þat Nicholas shal shapen him a wile
Þis sely Ialous housbond to by gyle
And if so be þe game wente a ryght
She sholde slepen in his arme al nyght
For þis was hir desir and his also
And right anon withouten wordes mo
Þis Nicholas wolde no lenger tarye
But doth ful softe in to his chambre carye
Boþ mete and drynke for a day or twey
And to hir housbond badde he her for to sey
If þat he axed after Nicholas
She shulde sey her nost where he was
Of al þat day she saugh hym not with ye
She trowed þat he was in maladye
For no crye þat hir mayde cowde him calle
He nolde answere for þinges þtat myȝt befalle
Þis passeth forth al þilke seterday
That Nicholas stille in his chambre lay
And yet and slepte or dide what hy liste
Tyl sonday þat the sonne goth to reste
Þis sely Carpenter haþ grete mervayle
Of Nicholas or what þyng mygh hym ayle
And seyd y am a drad by seynt Thomas
It stondith nat a right with Nicholas
God shelde þat he died sodenly
Þis world is now ful tykil sykerly
I sigh two corpus y born to chirch
Þat now a monday last I say þem wirch
Go vp qd he vnto his knaue a noūn
Clepe at his dore and knok with a stoon
Loke how it is and tel me boldely
Þis knave gooth him vp ful sturdyly
And at þe chambre dore while þat he stode
He cryed and knokked as þat he were wodde
What how what do ye Maister Nicholay
How may ye slepen al þe long day
But al for nought he herde nat a worde
An hole ful low he founde vpou þe borde
Þer as þe Cat was wont yn for to crepe
And at þat hole he loked yn ful depe
And at þe last he hedde of hym a sighte
Þis Nicholas sate euꝰer capyng vp right
As he hedde kyked on þe new mone
A downe he goth and tolde his maister sone
In what array he saugh þis ilke man
This Carpenter to blessen hym by gan
And seide helpe vs seint Frideswyde
A man wote litel what shal him bi tyde
Þis man is falle with his astromye
In somme wodnesse or som agonye
I thought ay wel how þat hit shulde be
Men sholde not know of goddes piriuete
I blessed be alwey a lewde man
Þat noght but only his byleve kan
So ferde another clerke with astromye
He walked in the feldes forto prye
Vpon the sterres what þer shuld by falle
Tyl he was in a Marle pytte y falle
He saigh nat þat but yet by seynt Nicholas
Me reweth sore of hende Nicholas
He shal be rated of his studyeng
Yf þat y may by Ihc heven kyng
Gete me a staf þat I may vnderspore
While þat þou Robyn hevest vp þe dore
He shal oute of his studeyng as y gesse
And to þe chambre dore he gan hym dresse
His knave was a strong karl for þe nones
And by þe haspe he haf it vp at ones
Into þe flore þe dore fil a nou
Þis Nicholas sat ay as stylle as a stou
And ever caped vpward in to þe eyre
Þis Carpenter wende he were in dispeyre
And hente him by the shuldres myghtyly
And shoke him harde and cryed spitously
What Nicholay what how loke a down
A wake and thynke on cristes passion
I crowche þe from elves and from wightys
Þer with þe nyght spel seyde he anon rightes
On foure halws on þe howse a bowte
And on þe thresshfolde at þe dore withoute
Ihu crist and seynt beneditht
Blesse þis hous from every wykked wight
For þe nyghteesuerie þe white patꝰer nr
Where wendestow þou seint petrus suster
And at þe last þis hende Nicholas
Gan for to sike sore and seyde allas
Shal all þe worlde be lost efte sones now
Þis Carpenter answered what seistow
What þinke on godde as we men doun þat swynk
This Nicholas answered fecch me drynk
And after wol I speke in pryvete
Of þing þat towch me and the
I wol telle it non other man certeyn
Þis Carpenter goth doun and cometh a gayn
And broȝt of myȝty ale a large quarte
And whan ich of hem hed drenke his part
This Nicholas fast þe dore shette
And down þe Carpenter by him sette
And seyd Iohn myn oost lef and dere
Þou shalt vpon my trowth swere me here
Þat to no wight þou shalt þis counsaill wrye
For it is cristes conseil þat y sye
And if þou telle it man þou art for lore
For this vengeaunce thou shalt have þerfore
Þat if þu wrye me þu shalt be wodde
Nay crist for bede it for []hishis holy blode
Qd tho þis sely man y am no labbe
Ne thogh y sey y nam noght leve to gabbe
Sey what þow wolt y shal it never telle
To childe ne wife by him þat harried helle
Now Iohn qd þis Nicholas y wol not lye
Y have founde in myn astrologye
As y have loked in þe mone bright
That now a monday next at quarter nyght
Shal falle a reyn and þat so wilde and wodde
That halfe so grete was never noyes floode
Þis worlde he seide in lasse than an houre
Shal al be dryent so hydows is þe shoure
Þis shal mankynd drench and lese his lyfe
Þis Carpenter answered allas my wyfe
And shal sho drench allas myn alison
For sorow of þis he fil almost a doun
And seide is þer no remedye in þis cas
Why ys for god qd hende Nicholas
Yf þu wolt wyrken after loore and reede
Þou maist not wirken after þyn owne hede
For þus seyth salamon þat was ful trewe
Wirke al by counsel and þou shalt not rewe
And if þou wirken wolt after gode counsel
I vnder taken with outen Mast or seyle
Yet shal y have hir þe and me
Hastowe not herde how saved was Noe
Whan þat owre lorde hedde warned hym byforn
Þat al þe worlde with water shulde be lorn
Yis qd þis Carpenter ful yore agou
Hastow nat herde qd Nicholas alsou
The sorowe of Noe with his felawship
Er þat he myght gete his wife to Ship
Hym hadde be lever I vndertake
At that tyme þan al his wetheres blake
Þat sho hedde hadde a ship hir sel allone
And þerfore wost þu was is best to done
Þis asketh hast and of an hasty þynge
Men may not preche ne make taryeng
Anon go gete vs fast in to þis Inne
A knedyng trogh or elles a kemelyn
For yche of vs but looke þat þey be large
In which we mowen skynne as in a barge
And han þer yn vitaille suffisaunt
But for a day fye on þe Remanaunt
Þe watꝰer shal a slake and gon a way
Vpon pryme vpon þe next day
But Robyn may not witte of þis þy knave
Ne eke þi mayde gille may I noȝt save
Axe þou noght whi for þogh þou axe me
I wolnot tellen goddes pryvitee
Suffiseth þe but if þi wittes madde
To have as grete a grace as Noe hadde
Þi wife shal y wel haven out of doute
Go now þi wey and spede þe here abowte
But when þou hast for hir and þe and me
I geten vs þis knedyng tubbes thre
Þan shaltow hange ham in the roves hye
Þat no man of oure purveaunce espye
And þou þus hast doun as I have seide
And hast oure vitaile feire in hem leyde
And eke an axe to smyte þe corde a two
When þe water cometh þat we may go
And breke an hole an high vpon þe gable
Vnto þe gardyn warde over þe stable
Þat we may frely passen forþ oure wye
Whan þat þe grete shoure is gon a waye
Þen shaltow swymme as mery y vndertake
As doth þe white doke after hir drake
Then wol I clepe how alison how Iohn
Be merye for þe flood shal passe anoūn
And thow seyn heile Maister Nicholay
Gode morou y see þe well for it is day
And then shal we be lordys al oure lyfe
Of al þe worlde as Noe and his wyfe
But of oon þyng y warne þe ful ryght
Be wel avysed on þat ilke nyght
Þat we byn entred in to þe shippes borde
That noon of vs speke noght a worde
Ne clepe ne crye but byn in his preyer
For it is goddes owne hest dere
Þy wife and þou mote honge ferre atwynne
For þat bitwixe yow shal be no syn
No more in lokyng ne þer shal in dede
Þis ordenaunce is seyde go god þe spede
To morowe at nyght when men byn al a slepe
Into oure knedyng tobbes wol we crepe
And sitten þer abydyng goddes grace
Go now þi wey y have no lenger space
To make of þis no lenger sermonyng
Men seyn þis sende þe wise and sey no þyng
Þowart so wite it nedeth þe nat teche
Go save oure life and that y the beseche
Þis sely Carpenter goth forth his wey
Ful ofte he seide allas and wel a way
And to his wyfe he tolde his pryvete
And she was ware and knew it bet þan he
What al þis queynt cas for to seye
But natheles sho ferde as sho wolde dye
And seyd allas go forth þi wey a nou
Helpe vs to scape an we byn dede ichou
I am þi trewe verrey wedden wyfe
Go dere spouce and helpe to save oure lyfe
Lo which a grete þing is affeccou
Men may dien of ymaginaciou
So depe may impꝰerssion ben take
Þis sely Carpenter bygynneth quake
Him þynkeþ verraylich þat he may se
Noes flod come walwyng as þe se
To drenchen alison his hony dere
He wepeth waileth maketh sory chere
He siketh with ful mony a sory slogh
And goth and geteth him a knedyng trogh
And after a tubbe an a kemelyn
And pryvely he sent hem to his In
And heng hem in þe roof in pryvetee
His owne honde he made laddres three
To clymbyn by þe stalkes ⁊ by þe ronges
Vnto þe tubbes hangyng in the balkes
And hem vitailled both trough and tubbe
With brede and chese and gode ale in a Iubbe
Suffising right y nough as for a day
But yet þat he hedde made al þis array
He sent his knave and eke his wench also
Vpon his nedes to london for to go
And on þe monday whan it drowe to nyght
He shette his dore withoute candel light
And dressed al þyng as hit shulde be
And shortely vp þey clomben al thre
Þey seten stylle well a forlong weye
Now pater noster clym seid Nicholaye
And clym seide Iohn and clym seide Alisou
Þis Carpenter seyde his devocion
And stille he sitte and biddeth his preyer
Awaytyng on the reyn if he it here
Þe dede slepe for very bysynesse
Fil on þis Carpenter right as I gesse
A boute corfewe tyme or litel more
For travaill of his gost he greueth sore
And ofte he routeþ for his hed lay a myslay
Downe of þe ladder stalketh Nicholay
And Alison ful softe a downe she spedde
Withoute wordes mo þey gon to bedde
Ther as þe Carpenter is wont to lye
Ther was þe Revel and þe Melodye
And thus lyen Alison and Nicholas
In bysinesse of mirth and in solas
Tyl þat þe belle of laudys gan to ryng
And freres in þe chauncel gan syng
Þis parissch clerk þis amorous absolou
Þat is for love alwey so woo by gon
Vpon þe munday was at Oseney
With companye hym to disporte and to pley
And asked a Chanon þat was a Cloistrere
Ful pryvery aftꝰer Iohn þe Carpentere
And he drough him a part oute of þe chirch
And seid y not y say him not here wirch
Seth seturday y trowe þat he be went
For tymber ther oure Abbat hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go
And dwellen atte grange a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn
Wher þat he be y kannot sothly seyn
Þis absolou ful Ioly was and light
And þought now is tyme to wake al nyȝt
For sikerly y saugh hym nought steryng
A boute his dore sen day by gan to spryng
So mote I thryve y shal at Cokkes crowe
Ful pryvely knokken at his wyndowe
Þat stant ful lowe vpon his boures walle
To Alison now wolly tellen alle
My love longyn for yet y shalnot mysse
Þat atte lest wey y shal hir kisse
Som maner comfort shal y have ꝑperfey
My mouth hath icched al þis longe day
Þat is a signe of kyssyng atte leste
Al nyght me met eke þat y was at a feste
Þer fore y wol go slepe an houre or twey
And al þe nyght þen wol I wake and pley
Whan þat þe first cokke hath crowe anon
Vp lest þis Ioly lover absoloūn
And him arrayeth gay at poynt devys
But first he chewed greyn greyn an lycorys
To smellen swete or he hed kemped his here
Vnder his tonge a trewelove he bare
For þerby wende he to be gracious
He renneth to þe Carpenters hous
And stylle he stont vnder þe shot wyndowe
Vnto his brest hit rawȝt it was so lowe
And softe he cougheth with a semy sown
What do ye honycombe swete alisone
My feire brid my swete synamome
A waketh lemman myn and speketh with me
Wel litel þynkyn ye vpon my wo
Þat for youre love I swete þer y go
No wonder is þaugh y swelt an swete
Y morne as doth a lambe after þe tete
I wys lemman y have such a love longyng
That like a turtyl trewe ys my mornyng
I maynat ete na more þan may a maide
Go fro þe wyndow Iakke foole she seyde
As helpe me god y wylnot be compame
I love a nother or ellis I were to blame
Wel bet þan þe bi ihu absoloūn
Go forþ þy wey or y wol cast a stou
And lete me slepe a twenty devell wey
Allas qd absolon and wel awey
Þat trewlove was ever so yvel by sette
Þen kys me sen it may be no bet
For ihc love and for þe love of me
Woltow go þy wey þꝰerwith qd she
Ye cꝰertys lemman qd this absoloūn
Þen make þe redy qd she y come a non
Þis absolon down sette hym on his knees
And seide y am a lorde at all degrees
For after þis y hope þer comyth more
Lemman þi grace and swete brydde þyn hore
Þe wyndow she vndoth and þat in haste
Have ydo qd she com and spede þe faste
Lest þat oure neghboures þe aspye
Þis absolon gan wipe his mouth full drye
Derke was þe nyght as picch or as þe cole
And at þe wyndow oute she putte her hole
And absolon him fel ne bette ne wers
But with his mouth he kist hir naked ers
Ful saverly yer he wer warre of þis
A bake he sterte and thought it was amys
Ful wel he wist a womman hath no berde
He felt a þing al rough and long of herede
And seyde fy allas what have I do
Te he qd she and clappte þe wyndow to
And absolon goth forþ a sory pas
A berd aberd seid hend Nicholas
By goddes corpus þis goth feire and well
Þis sely absolon herde euꝰery dell
And on his lippe he gan for angre byte
And to him selfe he seyde y shal þe quyte
Ho rubbeth who freteth now his lippes
With duste with sonde with strawe wtith cloþ wtith chippys
But absolon þat seyth ful ofte allas
My soule be take y vnto satanas
But me were lever þan al þis town qd he
Of þis dispite a wreken forto be
Allas qd he allas whi nedde y bleynt
His hote love was colde and al yqueynt
For fro þat tyme þat he hedde kist her hers
Of paramours he rought not a kars
For he was heled of his maladye
Ful ofte ꝑperamours he kan defye
And wepte as doth a childe þtat is y bete
A softe pas he goth him over þe strete
Vnto a smyth men clepen daun Gerveys
Þat in his forge smethed plow harneys
He sharpeth []aa share and cultur bysily
Þis absolon knokketh al esyly
And seyde vndo Gerveys and þat anon
Wat who artow . it am y absoloūn
What absolon what cristes swete tree
Why ryse ye so rathe ey benedicite
What eyleth you some gay girle god hit wote
Hath brought you þus vpon þe veritoot
By seint Note y wot wel what y mene
Þis absolon ne raught not a bene
Of al his pley ne worde agayn he yaf
He hedde more towe on his distaf
Þan Gerveys knew and seyde frende dere
Þat hote culture in þe chymeneye here
As lene it me I have þer with to doon
I wol bryng it þe agayn ful sone
Gerveys answered cꝰertes were it golde
Or in a poke nobles al vntolde
Þow shuldest have as I am trew smyth
Ey cristes fo who what wol ye do þꝰerwith
Þer of qd absolon be as be may
I shal wel telle it þe a nother day
And caught þe Culture by þe colde stele

l.seg: Fulle softe out at þe dore he gan to stele
And went vnto þe Carpenters walle
He cougheth first and knokketh þerwith alle

div.l: Vpon þe wyndow right as he ded er
Þis alison answered who is þer
Þat knokketh so y warant it a þefe
Nay nay qd he god wote my swete leef
I am thyn alison þy derelyng
Of golde qd he y have broght þe aryg
My moder yaf it me so god me save
Ful fyne it is and þer to wel y grave
Þis wol y yeven þe yf þou me kysse
Þis Nicholas was reson vp to pisse
And þought he wolde amenden al þe Iape
He shulde kysse his ers er he scape
And vp þe wyndow did he hastyly
And oute his ers he putteth pryvely
Over þe buttok to þe hanche boon
And þer with spake þis clerk þis absolou
Speke swete bridde y not wher þou arte
Þis Nicholas a non let flee a farte
As grete as hit hedde byn a thonder dynt
Þat with þe stroke he was wel nygh ybleynt
And he was redy with his Iren wote
And Nicholas in þe ers he smote
Of goth þe skyn an hundebrede a boute
Þe hote culter brende so his toute
Þat for þe smert he wende forto dye
As he were wodde for wo he gan to crye
Helpe watꝰer watꝰer helpe for goddes hert
Þis Carpenter out of his clumber stert
And herd won crye watꝰer as he were woode

Here endeth the Reues tale . And
here begynneth the prolage of þe Cookes tale
The Coke of londou while þe Reve spake
For Ioy him þought he claued him on his bake
Ha ha qd he for cristes passiou
This miller hedde a sharp conclusiou
Vpon his Argument of herbergage
Wel seide salamon in his language
Ne brynge nought every man in to þyn hous
For herberwynge by nyght is ꝓproelous
Wel ought a man avysed for to be
Whom þat he brought in to his pryvete
I prey to god so eve sorow and care
If euer sith y hithte hogge of ware
Herde y a miller better y sette of a clerke
He hed a iape of malice in þe derke
But god forbede þat we stynten here
And þerfore yif ye vouchesaf to heere
A tale of me þat am a pore man
I wolle you telle as wel as I kan
A litel Iape þat fille in oure Citee
Oure host answered y graunt it þe
Now telle on Rogger loke þat it be gode
For mana a pastey hastow latyn blode
And many a Iak of dover hastow solde
Þat haþ byn twyes hote and twyes colde
Of many a pilgrymhastow cristes curs
For of þi ꝑperslye yet þey fare þe wors
Þat þey han eten in þy stopped goos
For in þi shoppe is many a flye loos
Now telle on gentil Roger by þy name
But yet y prey þe benot wroth for game
A man may sey ful sooth in game and pley
Þou seyst ful sooth qd Roger by my fey
But sooth pley quade pley as þe flemmyng seith
And therfore harry Baily by þy feith
Be þou not wroth er we departe heere
Þough þat my tale be of an hostelere
But natheles I wil nought telle it yet
But er we part y wis þou shalt be queyt
And ther with al he lough and made cheere
And seyd his tale as ye shal after heere
Here begynneth the Cookes tale
A prentys whilom dwelled in oure sitee
And of a crafte of vitellers was he
Gaylerd he was as gyldfynch in þe shawe
Broun as a bery a ꝓpropre short felawe
With lokkys blake y kembed ful fetisly
Dauncen he kowde so wel and Iolyly
Þat he was cleped perkyn reveloure
He was as ful of love and ꝓproamoure
As is þe hyve ful of hony swete
Wel was þe wench þat hym myȝt mete
And at euery bridale wolde he synge ⁊ hoppe
He loved bet þe taverne þan he dede þe shoppe
For when þer was eny rydyng in chepe
Out of þe shoppe þeder wolde he lepe
Til þat he hedde al þe sight y seyn
And daunced wel he noldnot come a gayn
And gadered hym a mayny of his sort
To hoppe and synge and make such disport /
With Rechneuer and recheles þis lesson he lerys
With waste and with wranglere his owne pley ferys
With lytghthonde and with lykorouse mowth with vnschamfast
With drynke more ⁊ with drawe a bak her thryst is y past
With malaperte ⁊ with mysseavysed suche meyny þey hight
That wolle do but a lytul tylle her dyuer bedyght
Thus þey stevyn whan þey myght mete
To pley at þe dyse in suche a prevey strete
For in londoūn þer was none Apprentyse
That feirer couth caste a scharpe þew of dyse
Than couthe Perkyn ⁊ þer to he was free
Large of his dispence in place of prevytee
With Magot ⁊ with Mylsent whan þat he mette
The bagge with þe powder anon was vnknette
His purs was inperfit he couthe notwelle kepe
Yet let vs be mery while oure sire is aslepe
With Pyes ⁊ with Pykrels with wyues moste swete
With loche ⁊ with lamprey þe childe myght not ete
The Tapster þe Taverner þe koke was nedy
Wolde clepe on perkyn for his purs was so redy
And þat fownde his Maister welle in his chaffare
For euery other day his boxe was lefte bare
An vnthrysty begynnyng for yong or for olde
A Prentyse to be a reueloure ⁊ ꝑperamours to holde
That bargeyn no man so sore schalle Abye
As his Maister þat hath no parte of his melodye
For theft ⁊ Ryot they beth incounertyble
Alle thogh he can pley on Getern ⁊ Rybible
Ravelle and trouthe as in a lowe degree
They mow mow not acorde al day men it see
When þy purs is penyles where schalt þou haue more
Thou þat wylt not þe ottupie no thyng therfore
Revel ys ordeyned to hem þat mow pay
But prentise ne pore man þey mowe not away
Euelle sponne wolle at the laste wolle come oute
They þou kepe it neuer so prevey in alytelle cloute
Thus þe Ioly prentyse with his maister abode
Tylle he was nye oute of his prenteshode
Alle thogh he were snybbyd bothe erly ⁊ late
Yet some tyme he was ladde with revel to newgate
But at þe laste as his Maister hym be thought
To over se his papire ⁊ hym thorow sought
Vppon a proverbe þat seith þis same worde
Better ys rotten Appulle out of an hurde
Than for to let hem rote alle the remenaunte
And ryght so it fareth by Aryotes seruaunte
It is lasse harme for to let hym pace
Then for to schende al þe seruaunts in þe place
Euen as a stabbed schepe in þe folde
Alle a flocke wolle defyle both yonge ⁊ olde
Ryght euen so a febel seruaunt may
Distruye fourty of his felaws in a day
Therfore his Maister gaffe hym acquytaunce
And bade hym goe with sorowe ⁊ myschaunce
Better ys betyme to voyde suche a clerke
The lenger he abydeth þe wors is his werke
He þat his Maister no profite wolle wynne
Y holde hym better out of þe hous þan with ynne
And thus þe Ioly Prentys had leve
Now let hym rouel alle þe nyght or leue
Ther ys no thiffe with out alowke
That helpeth hym to waste ⁊ to sowke
Or that he brybe can or oght borowe may
Anon he sent his bedde and alle his araye
Vnto acompere of his owne sorte
That loued welle þe Dyse Ryot ⁊ disporte
A wife he hadde that helde for contenaunce
A schoppe and ever sche pleyed for his sustenaunce
What thorowe hym selfe and his felawe þat sought
Vnto a myschefe bothe þey were broght
The coue y dampned to presoūn ꝑperpetually
The tother to deth for he couthe not of clergye
And therfore yonge men lerne while ye may
That with mony dyuers thoghtes beth prycked al þe day
Remembre you what myschefe cometh of mysgouernaunce
Thus mowe ye lerne worschep ⁊ come to substaunce
Thenke how grace and governaunce hath broght he a boune
Many þore manys son chese state of þe towne
Euer rewle the after þe beste man of name
And god may grace þe to come to þe same
Here endeth the Cokes tale

To hir biwryed I my consel al
For hedde myn housbonde pissed on a wal
Or don a thyng þat shulde have cost his life
To hir and to a nother worthi wife
And to my Nece which y loved wel
I wolde have tolde his consel every del
And so y dede ful often god it wote
Þat made his face ful often rede and hoot
For verrey shame and blame him selfe for he
Hedde tolde to me so grete a pryvetee
And so by fel þat onys in alente
So often tymes I to my gosyb wente
For ever yet I loved to be gay
And forto walke averel March and may
From hous to hous to here sumdry talis
That Iankyn Clerke and my gosyb dam alys
And y my selfe in to veldes wente
Myn housbonde was at londou al þe lente
Ihedde þe better leyser for to pley
And forto see And eke for to be sey
Of lusty folke where wist I what my grace
Was shapen for to be and in what place
Ther fore y made my visitacions
To vigiles and to processions
To prechynge eke and to þese pilgrimages
To pleyes of miracles and mariages
And wered vpon my gay skarlet gites
Þise wormys ne these mouthes ne þise Mites
Vpon my pyl frete hem never adel
And wostow why for þey were vsed wel
Now wolly tellen for þe what happeth me
I sey þat in þe feldes walked we
Tyl trewly we hed such daliaunce
This clerke and I that of my purveiaunce
I spake to hym and seyde hy how þat he
If y were wedewe shulde wedde me
For certeynly y sey for no bolaunce
Yet was y never withouten purveaunce
Of Mariage ne of othir thinges eke
I holde a mouse hert not worth aleeke
Þat hath but oon hole for to sterte to
And if þat faile þen is al ydo
But now sir lete me syn what shal I seyn
A ha by god y have my tale agayn
Whan þat my ferth housbonde was on bere
I wepte al gate and made sory chere
As wyues moten for it is vsage
And with my couꝰerchef couer my visage
But for þat y was purveyed of a make
I wepte but smale and þat y vndertake
To chirch was myn housbonde born a morowe
With neghborues þat for him maden sorowe
And Iankyn oure clerk was on of tho
As helpe me go whan þat I saw hem go
After þe bere me þought he hed apeyre
Of legges and of feet so clene and feyre
Þat al myn hert y yaf vnto his hoold
He was I trow twydy wynter olde
And I was fourty if y shal seye soth
But yet I hed alwey a Coltes toth
Gat tothed y was and that be come me wel
I hed the prente of dame venus seel
As helpe me god y was a lusty oon
And feire and riche and yonge and wel bygon
And trewly as myn housbondy tolde me
I hedde þe best quoniam þat myȝt bee
Myn ascendent was Taur and Mars þe Inne
Allas allas þat ever love was synne
I folowed ay myn inclinacou
By vertew in my constillacou
Þat made me I koude nought with drawe
My chambre of venus fro a gode felawe
What shulde y sey but at þe monthes ende
Þis Ioly clerke Iankyn þat was so hende
Hath weddet me with grete solempnite
And to hym yaf y al þe londe and fee
Þat ever was me yeven þer be fore
But afterward repented me ful sore
He nolde suffre no thynge of my luste
By god he smote me oones on þe luste
For þat y rent out of his booke a leef
Þat of þe stroke my nere wexe alle deef
Styborne I was as Is a lyonas
And of my tonge a very Iangleras
And walke y wolde as I have don byforn
From house to hous al þogh he heddit sworn
For which he often tymes wolde preche
And me of olde Romayn gestes teche
How he Symplicius Gallus lefte his wyfe
And he for soke for tꝰerme of his lyfe
Noght but for open heved he hir say
Lokyng oute of his dore vpon a day
Anothir Romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wyf was at a Somꝰers game
Withoute his wetyng he forsoke hir eke
And thenne wolde he vpon his bible seke
That ilke proverbe of Ecclesiaste
Where he commaundeth and for bedeth faste
Men shulnot suffre hir wyves go roule a boute
Þen wolde he seyn þis with outen dowte
Who so þat byldeth his hous al of salves
And priketh his blynde hors over the falowys
And suffereth his wife to go seken halous
Is worthi to honged on þe galowys
But al for nought I sette nought an hawe
Of his proverbys ne of his old sawe
Ny woldnot of him corrected be
I hate him þat my vices telleth me
And so don mo god wot of vs þan I
This made him wode with me al outerly
I nolde nold nought for bere him in no cas
Now wol I sey you soth by seint Thomas
Whi þat y rent oute of his booke a lefe
For whiche he smote me so þat y was deef
He hedde abooke þat gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede al way
He clepeth it Valerie and Theofarste
At which bok he lokeþ al wey ful faste
And eke þer was som tyme at Rome a clerke
A Cardinal þat hight Ierome
That made aboke a yenst Iovinian
In which boke eke þer was Tertulou
Crisippis Trotula and helowys
That was abbesse nat fer fro parys
And eke the parables of Salamon
Ouydes Art and bokys many oon
And al these wore bounde in on volume
And every nyght and day was his custume
Whan y hedde leyser and vacacou
For other worldely ocupciou
To Reden in þis boke of wiked wyves
He knewe of hem mo legendes and lyves
Than byn of gode wyfes in þe Bible
For trusteth wel it is an Inpossible
That eny clerke wol speke gode of wyves
But if it be of holy seintes lyves
Nof non othir womma neuer þe mo
Who peynteþ þe leon tel me who
By god yf wymmen hedde writen storyes
As clerkys han with Inne hir Oratories
Þey wolde have wreten of men more wykkednesse
Than al þe mark of Adam may redresse
The children of Mercury and of venus
Been in hr wirchyng ful contrarius
Mercurye loveth wisedom and science
And venus loveth ryot and dispence
And for hir diuers disposicion
Ech faileth in othirs exaltacou
And þus god wote Mercury is disolate
In pisces where venus is exaltate
And venus faileth þer mꝰercurye is reysed
Therfore no wōmman of clerkys is preysed
The Clerke when he is olde and may noght do
Of venus werkis worth his olde sho
Þen sit he down and writ in his dotage
That wymmen kan not kepe hir mariage
But now to purpos whi I tolde þe
Þat y was beten for a boke ꝑperde
Vpon a nyght Iankyn þat was oure sire
Radde on his boke as he sate by þe fire
Of Eva first þat for hir wikkednesse
Was al man kynde brought to wrecchednesse
Þo radde he me how sampson lost his herys
Slepyng his lemnan kut hit with hir sherys
Þorough which tresou lost he both his yen
Þo redde he me if þat y shal nat lyen
Of hercules and of his dianyr
Þat caused hym to sette him selfe a fire
Ne thyng for gate he þe sorow and wo
That socrates hedde with his wives two
How santipa cast pisse vpon his hede
Þis sely man sate stille as he were dede
He wipte his hede namore durst he seyn
But er þat thondir stynt comyth arayn
O phasispha þat was þe quene of Crete
For shrewdenesse him þought þe tale swete
Fy speke na more it is a grisly þynge
Of hir horrible lust and hir likynge
Of Clitermystra for hir lecherye
Þat falsly made hir housbonde for to dye
He red hit with ful gode devociou
He tolde me eke for what Occasiou
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his lyf
Myn housbonde hedde a legent of his wyfe
Exiphilem þat for an Ouch of golde
Hath pryvely vnto þe grekis tolde
Where þat hir housbande hidde hym in a place
For which he hedde at Thebes sory grace
Of lyma tolde he me and of lucye
Þey bothe made hir housbondes for to dye
That oon for love þat other was for hate
Lyma hir housbonde vpon an even late
Empoysened hath for þat she was his fo
Lucya likorus loved hir housbond so
That for he shulde al wey vpon hir thynke
She yaf him such a maner of love drynke
Þat he was ded er it were by þe morowe
And þus algates housbondes han sorewe
Þen tolde he me how þat oon latumyus
Compleyned vnto his felawe arryus
That in his gardyn growed such a tree
On which he seide how þat his wyves þree
Hengen hem self for hertus dispitus
O leve brother qd this arrius
Yf me a plante of þilke blessed tre
And in my gardyn planted it shal be
Of later date of wyves hath he radde
Þat sōmme han sley hir housbondys in hir bedde
And lete hir lechour dight hir al þe nyght
Whan þat þe corpus lay in þe flore vp ryght
And soume han dryve naylis in hir brayn
While þey slepe and þus þei han hem slayn
Somme han yeve hem poysen in hir drynke
He spake more harme þan hert may thinke
And þer with al he knewe of mo ꝓproverbes
Þan in þis worlde þer growen grasse or herbys
Bet is qd he þyn habitacou
Be with alyou or a fowle dragou
Þan with a womma vsyng forto chyde
Bet is qd he high in þe rofe abyde
Þan with an Angry wyf down in the hous
Thei byn so wilked and contrarious
They haten þat hir housbondes loueth ay
He seid a womma cast hir shame a wey
When sho cast of hir smok and futhermo
A feire womman but if she be chast also
Is like a gold ryng in a sowes nose
Who wollde leve or who wold suppose
The who þat in myn hert was and pyne
And whan y se he wolde never fyne
To reden on þis cursed boke al nyȝt
Al sodeynly þre leues have y pight
Out of his boke right as he radde and eke
I with my fist so toke hym on þe cheke
That in þe fire he fil bakward adoun
And vp he sterte and doth as a wodde lyou
And with his fiste he smote me on the hede
Þat in þe flore y lay as y were dede
And whan he say how stille þat y lay
He was agast and wolde have fled his wey
Til at þe last oute of my slough y breyde
O hastow slayn me fals theof y seyde
And for my londe þus hastow murthred me
Er y be dede yet wol y kysse the
And nere he cam and kneled feyre a doun
And seyde dere sustre Alisou
As helpe me god I shal þe never smyte
Þat I have doon it is þi selfe to wyte
For yeve it me and þat y the byseche
And yet eft sones I hit hym on þe cheke
And seid þef þus mochel am y wreke
Now wol I dye y may no lenger speke
But at þe last with mochel kare and wo
We fylle to accorde by vs selfe two
And yaf me al þe bridel in myn honde
To have þe governauns of hous and londe
And of his tonge and his honde also
And made him brenne his boke anon right tho
And when þat I hed geten vnto me
By maistrie al þe sovereynte
And þat he seid myn owne trew wyfe
Do as þe lust þe terme of al þy lyfe
Kepe þyn honoure and kepe eke myn estate
After þat day we hadden never debate
God helpe me so y was to him as kynde
As eny wife from denmarke vnto Inde
And so trew and so was he to me
I prey to god þat sitte in magistete
So blisse his soule for his mercy deere
Now wol y sey my tale if ye wol here
Þe frere lough when he hedde harde alþis
Now dame qd he so have y Ioy or blisse
This is a longe pꝰeramble of a tale
And whan þe somnoure herd þe frere gale
Lo qd þe somnoure goddy armys two
A frere wol entermete hym euꝰermo
Lo gode men a flye and eke a frere
Wol falle in every dyssch and matere
What spekest thou of preambulacou
What amble or trot or pees or go sitte doun
Þou lettest oure disporte in þis manere
Ye wiltow sir Somnoure qd the frere
Now by my feith y shal er þat y go
Telle of a Sūnnoure suche a tale or two
That alle þe folke shal laughen in þis place
Now ellis frere y wol be shrewe þy face
Qd þis Somnoure and I be shrewe me
But if y telle talis two or three
Of freris er I come to Sydigborn
Þat I shal make þyn hert forto morn
For wel y wot þi pacience is gon
Oure hoost cryed pes and þat anon
And seyd lette þe wommān telle hir tale
Ye fare as folke þat dronken byn of ale
Do dame telle forth youre tale and þis beste
Al redy sir qd she right as you list
If I have licence of þis worthi frere
Yis dame qd he telle forth and I wol heere
Here endeth the Prolage of the wyfe of Bathe ; And here begynneth her tale ;

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the tale of the Wyf of Bathe
(base) IN tholde dayes of the kyng Arthour
(base) Of which that Britons speken greet honour
(base) Al was this land fulfild of Fairye
(base) The Elf queene with hir ioly compaignye
(base) Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede
(base) This was the olde opynyoun as I rede
(base) I speke of many hundred yerys ago
(base) But now kan no man se none Elues mo
(base) For now the grete charitee and prayeres
(base) Of lymytours and othere holy freres
(base) That serchen euery lond and euery streem
(base) As thikke as motes in the sonne beem
(base) Blessynge halles chambres kichenes boures
(base) Citees Burghes Castels hye Toures
(base) Thropes Bernes Shipnes Dayeryes
(base) This maketh that ther been no fairyes
(base) For ther as wont to walken was an Elf
(base) Ther walketh now the lymytour hymself
(base) In vndermelys and in morwenynges
(base) And seith his matyns and his holy thynges
(base) As he gooth in his lymytacioun
(base) Wommen may go saufly vp and down
(base) In euery bussh or vnder euery tree
(base) Ther is noon oother Incubus but he
(base) And he ne wol doon hem but dishonour
(base) And so bifel that this kyng Arthour
(base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
(base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
(base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce
(base) For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle
(base) That we nyl kike for he seith vs sooth
(base) Assay and he shal fynde it that so dooth
(base) For be we neuer so vicious with Inne
(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne
(base) And somme seyn that greet delit han we
(base) For to be holden stable and eek secree
(base) And in o purpos stedefastly to dwelle
(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle
(base) But that tale is nat worth a Rake stele
(base) Pardee we wommen konne no thyng hele
(base) Witnesse on Mida wol ye heere the tale
(base) Ouyde amonges othere thynges smale
(base) Seyde Mida hadde vnder his longe herys
(base) Growynge vpon his heed two Asses erys
(base) The which vice he hidde as he best myghte
(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte
(base) That saue his wyf ther wiste of it na mo
(base) He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
(base) He preyed hire that to no creature
(base) She sholde tellen of his disfigure
(base) She swoor hym nay for al this world to wynne
(base) She nolde do that vileynye or syn
(base) To make hir housbonde han so foul a name
(base) She nolde nat telle it for hir owene shame
(base) But nathelees hir thoughte that she dyde
(base) That she so longe sholde a conseil hyde
(base) Hir thoughte it swal so soore aboute hir herte
(base) That nedely som word hir moste asterte
(base) And sith she dorste nat telle it to no man
(base) Doun to a Marys faste by she ran
(base) Til she cam there hir herte was a fyre
(base) And as a Bitore bombleth in the Myre
(base) She leyde hir mouth vnto the water down
(base) Biwrey me nat thow water with thy sown
(base) Quod she to thee I telle it and namo
(base) Myn housbonde hath longe Asses erys two
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Now is myn herte al hool now it is oute
(base) I myghte no lenger kepe it out of doute
(base) Heere may ye see thogh we a tyme abyde
(base) Yet out it moot we kan no conseil hyde
(base) The remenant of the tale if ye wol heere
(base) Redeth Ouyde and ther ye may it leere
(base) This knyght of which my tale is specially
(base) Whan that he say he myghte nat come ther by
(base) This is to seye what wommen louen moost
(base) With Inne his brest ful sorweful was the goost
(base) But hom he gooth he myghte nat soiorne
(base) The day was come that homward moste he torne
(base) And in his wey it happed hym to ryde
(base) In al this care vnder a Forest syde
(base) Wher as he say vpon a daunce go
(base) Of ladyes twenty foure and yet mo
(base) Toward the whiche daunce he drow ful yerne
(base) In hope that som wisdom sholde he lerne
(base) But certeynly er he cam fully there
(base) Vanysshed was this daunce he nyste where
(base) No creature say he that bar lyf
(base) Saue on the grene he say sittynge a wyf
(base) A fouler wight ther may no man deuyse
(base) Agayn the knyght this olde wyf gan ryse
(base) And seyde sire knyght heer forth ne lyth no wey
(base) Tel me what that ye seken by youre fey
(base) Par auenture it may the bettre be
(base) This olde folk konne muchel thyng quod she
(base) My leeue moder quod this knyght certeyn
(base) I nam but deed but if that I kan seyn
(base) What thyng it is that wommen moost desire
(base) Koude ye me wisse I wolde wel quyte youre hyre
(base) Plight me thy trouthe here in myn hand quod she
(base) The nexte thyng that I requere thee
(base) Thow shalt it do if it lye in thy myght
(base) And I wol telle it yow er it be nyght
(base) Haue here my trouthe quod the knyght I graunte
(base) Thanne quod she I dar me wel auaunte
(base) Thy lyf is sauf for I wole stonde ther by
(base) Vpon my lyf the queene wol seye as I
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lat see which is the prouddeste of hem alle
(base) That wereth on a couerchief or a calle
(base) That dar seye nay of that I shal thee teche
(base) Lat vs go forth withouten lenger speche
(base) Tho rowned she a pistel in his ere
(base) And bad hym to be glad and haue no fere
(base) Whan they be comen to the Court this knyght
(base) Seyde he hadde holde his day as he had hight
(base) And redy was his answere as he sayde
(base) Ful many a noble wyf and many a mayde
(base) And many a widwe for that they ben wise
(base) The queene hir self sittyng as Iustise
(base) Assembled been this answere for to here
(base) And afterward this knyght was bode appere
(base) To euery wight comanded was silence
(base) And that the knyght sholde telle in audience
(base) What thyng that worldly wommen louen best
(base) This knyght ne stood nat stille as dooth a best
(base) But to his question anon answerde
(base) With manly voys that al the court it herde
(base) My lige lady generally quod he
(base) Wommen desire to haue souereyntee
(base) As wel ouer hir housbonde as hir loue
(base) And for to been in maistrie hym aboue
(base) This is youre mooste desir thogh ye me kille
(base) Dooth as yow list I am here at youre wille
(base) In al the Court ne was ther wyf ne mayde
(base) Ne wydwe that contraryed that he sayde
(base) But seyden he was worthy han his lyf
(base) And with that word vp stirte that olde wyf
(base) Which that the knyght say sittyng on the grene
(base) Mercy quod she my souereyn lady queene
(base) Er that youre Court departe do me right
(base) I taughte this answere vnto the knyght
(base) For which he plighte me his trouthe there
(base) The firste thyng I wolde hym requere
(base) He wolde it do if it laye in his myght
(base) Bifore the court thanne preye I thee sire knyght
(base) Quod she that thow me take vnto thy wyf
(base) For wel thow woost that I haue kept thy lyf
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) If I seye fals sey nay vpon thy fey
(base) This knyght answerde allas and weilawey
(base) I woot right wel that swich was my biheste
(base) For goddes loue as chees a newe requeste
(base) Taak al my good and lat my body go
(base) Nay thanne quod she I shrewe vs bothe two
(base) For thogh that I be foul old and poore
(base) I nolde for al the metal ne for oore
(base) That vnder erthe is graue or lith aboue
(base) But if thy wyf I were and eek thy loue
(base) My loue quod he nay my dampnacioun
(base) Allas that any of my nacioun
(base) Sholde euere so foule disparaged be
(base) But al for noght thende is this that he
(base) Constreyned was he nedes moste hir wedde
(base) And taketh his olde wyf and goth to bedde
(base) Now wolden som men seye par auenture
(base) That for my necligence I do no cure
(base) To tellen yow the ioye and al tharray
(base) That at the feste was that ilke day
(base) To which thyng shortly answere I shal
(base) I seye ther nas no ioye ne feste at al
(base) Ther nas but heuynesse and muche sorwe
(base) For priuely he wedded hire on morwe
(base) And al day after hidde hym as an Owle
(base) So wo was hym his wyf looked so foule
(base) Greet was the wo the knyght hadde in his thoght
(base) Whan he was with his wyf a bedde ybroght
(base) He walweth and he turneth to and fro
(base) His olde wyf lay smylyng euere mo
(base) And seyde o deere housbonde benedicite
(base) Is this the lawe of kyng Arthures hous
(base) Is euery knyght of his thus daungerous
(base) I am youre owene loue and youre wyf
(base) I am she which that saued hath youre lyf
(base) And certes yet ne dide I yow neuere vnright
(base) Why fare ye thus with me this firste nyght
(base) Ye faren lyk a man hadde lost his wit
(base) What is my gilt for goddes loue tel it
(base) And it shal ben amended if I may
(base) Fareth euery knyght thus with his wyf as ye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Amended quod this knyght allas nay nay
(base) It wol nat ben amended neuere mo
(base) Thow art so loothly and so old also
(base) And ther to comen of so lowe a kynde
(base) That litel wonder is thogh I walwe and wynde
(base) So wolde god myn herte wolde breste
(base) Is this quod she the cause of youre vnreste
(base) Ye certeynly quod he no wonder is
(base) Now sire quod she I koude amende al this
(base) If that me liste er it were dayes thre
(base) So wel ye myghte bere yow vnto me
(base) But for ye speken of swich gentillesse
(base) Nat of oure eldres for hir old richesse
(base) For thogh they yeue vs al hir heritage
(base) For which we clame to been of hir parage
(base) Yet may they nat biquethe for no thyng
(base) To noon of vs hir vertuous lyuyng
(base) That made hem gentil men ycalled be
(base) And bad vs folwen hem in swich degree
(base) Wel kan the wise poete of Florence
(base) That highte Dant speken in this sentence
Lo in such maner ryme is dantys tale
Ful selde vp rysell by his braunches smale
Prowesse of man for god of his godnesse
Wol þat of hym we clayme oure gentlenesse
For of oure eldres may we no thing playnee
But temporal þyng þat ma may hurte and maym
Eke every wight wote eke as wel as I
If gentilnesse we planted naturally
Vnto acerteyn lynages doun þe lyne
Pryvee and apert þen wolde þey never fyne
To don of gentlenesse þe feire office
Þey myght do no vilenye or vice
Take fyre and be it in þe derke hous
Bytwyxt þis and þe mount of kaukasous
And let men shit þe dores and go þenne
Yet wol þe fire as feire lye and brenne
As twenty thousand men myȝt be holde
His office naturel ay wol it holde
Vp ꝑperil of my life til þat it dye

seg.seg: As ys descended out of olde rychesse
That therfore schulden ye be gentlemen
Such arrogance ys not worth an hen
Look who that ys most vertuous alway
Pryvey and a perte and moste entendeth ay
To do the gentle dedis that he can
Take hym for the grettest gentle man
Of criste wolle we clayme oure gentlenesse

div.l: Here may ye se wel how þat genterye
Is nat annexed to possession
Sich folke ne don hir oꝑperacou
Alwey as doth þe fyre in his kynde
For god it wot men may wel often fynde
A lordes sonne do shame and vilanye
And he þat wol have prys of his gentry
For he was born in a gentil hous
And hedde is eldres noble an vertous
And nyl him selve do no gentil dedis
Ne folowe his gentil auncetry þat ded is
He nys nat gentil be he duke or Erle
For vilens synful dedis makith a cherle
For gentilnesse nis but renomee
Of þyn auncestres for hir high bonteēm
Which is a straynge þynge to þy ꝑpersone
Thi gentilesse cometh fro god allone
Þenne cometh oure verray gentilnesse of grace
It was no þyng bequeth vs with oure place
Þenkeþ hou noble as seith valerius
Was thilke tullius hostellius
Þat oute of povert ros to high noblenesse
Redeth Senek and redeth eke Boesse
Þer shal ye seen exprees þat no drede is
Þat he is gentil þat doth gentil dedis
And ther fore leve housbonde y this conclude
Al were it þat myn Auncestres weren rude
Yet may þe high god and so hope I
Graunt me grace to lyven vertuosly
Þan am y gentil when þat I bygynne
To leven vertuosly and weyue synne
And ther as ye of povert me repreve
Þe high god on whom þat we by leve
In wilful pouerte chees to lyve his lyfe
And certis euꝰery man mayden or wif
May vnderstond ihu heven kyng
Ne wold not chese vicious lyvyng
Glad pouerte is an honest þing certeyn
This wol senek and other clerkys seyn
Whoso þat halt him payed of his pouerte
I holde him riche and hedde he nat a shirte
He þat covetith is a poure wight
For he wolde han þat is not in is myght
But he þat noght hath ne covetith have
Is riche al þough ye holde him but a knave
Verray poverte is syn proprely
Iuuemal sith of poverte merily
Þe pore man whan he goth by þe wey
By forn þe theues he may synge and pley
Poverte is hateful gode and as y gesse
A ful grete brynger out of bisinesse
A grete amender eke of sapience
To him þat takith hit in pacience
Povert is þis al þough it seme alenge
Possessiou þat no wight wol chalenge
Pover ful often when a man is lowe
Maketh his god and eke him selve to knowe
Pevert a spectacle is as þynketh me
Þorogh which he may his frendes se
And therfore sir seyn þat I nought you greue
Of my pouert namore ye may me repreve
Now sir of elde ye repreve me
And certys sir though non auctoritee
Were in no booke ye gentilis of honoure
Seyn þat men shulde an olde wight don fauour
And clepe him fader for youre gentiles
And auctours shal y fynden as I gesse
Now þer ye sey y am foule and olde
Þen drede you noght to byn a Cokewolde
For filþe and elde also mote I the
Byn grete wardeyns of chastite
But natheles seyn y knowe youre delite
I shal fulfil youre worldly appetite
Chees now qd she oon of þis þynges twey
To have me foule and wold til þat y dey
And be to you atrewe humble wife
And never you displese in al my lyfe
Or ellis ye wol han me yonge and feyre
And take youre a venture of þe repaire
That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
Or in sōmme other place may wel be
No chees youre selven wheþer ye liketh
Þis knyght aviseth him and sore siketh
But at the last he seid in þis manere
My lady and my wyf and my lefe so dere
I putte me in youre wise governaunce
Cheseth youre selve which may be most plesance
And most honoure to you and me also
I do no force þe whether of þe two
For as you liketh it suffiseth me
Thenne have I gete of you þe maistr qd she
Seyn y may chees and governe as my lest
Ye certis wife qd he y holde it best
Kis me qd she we be no lenger wroth
For by my trouth y wol be to you both
Þis is to sey boþe fair and gode
I prey to god þat y mote sterven wode
But y to yow be as gode and trewe
As ever was wife seyn þat þe worlde was newe
And bote I ben to morn as feire to sene
As eny lady Emparise or quenēm
As is bitwyxt þe est and eke þe west
Do by my lif and deth right as ye list
Cast vp þe Curteyn loke how it is
And whan þe knyght say verrayly al this
Þat she so faire was and so yonge þer to
For Ioy he hent hir in his armes two
And his hert bathed in a bathe of blisse
A thousand tyme a rewe he gan hir kesse
And she abeyed him in every thing
Þat might do hym plesaunce and likyng
And thus þey leve vnto hir lyves ende
In ꝑperfite Ioy and ihu Crist vs sende
Housbandes meke yonge and fressh a bedde
And grace touꝰerbede hem þat we wedde
And eke y prey ihu shorte hir lyves
Þat wolnot be gouerned by hir wyves
And olde and angry nygardys of dispence
God sende hem sone verray pestellence
Here endeth the wyfes tale of Bathe
(base) ¶ The prologe of the Freres tale
(base) This worthy lymytour/ this noble frere
(base) He made alwey / a manere louryng cheere
(base) Vpon the Somnour/ but for honestee
(base) No vileyns word / as yet to hym spak he
(base) But at the laste / he seyde vnto the wyf
(base) ¶ Dame quod he god yeue yow right good lyf
(base) Ye han heer touched / al so mote I thee
(base) In scole matere / greet difficultee
(base) Ye han seyd muche thyng right wel I seye
(base) But dame / here as we ryden by the weye
(base) Vs nedeth nat to speken / but of game
(base) And lete auctoritees / on goddes name
(base) To prechyng and to scole of clergye
(base) But if it like / to this compaignye
(base) I wol yow / of a Somnour telle a game
(base) Pardee / ye may wel knowe by the name
(base) That of a Somnour / may no good be sayd
(base) I praye / that noon of yow / be ypayd
(base) A somnour / is a rennere vp and doun
(base) With mandementz / for fornicacioun
(base) And is ybet at euery townes ende
(base) ¶ Oure hoost tho spak / a sire ye sholde be hende
(base) And curteys / as a man of youre estaat
(base) In compaignye / we wol no debaat
(base) Telleth youre tale / and lat the Somnour be
(base) ¶ Nay quod the Somnour / lat hym seye to me
(base) What so hym list whan it comth to my lot
(base) By god / I shal hym quyten euery grot
(base) I shal hym telle / which a gret honour
(base) It is / to be a flaterynge lymytour
(base) And of / many another manere cryme
(base) Which nedeth nat rehercen / for this tyme
(base) And his office / I shal hym telle ywys
(base) ¶ Oure hoost answerde / pees namoore of this
(base) And after this / he seyde vnto the frere
(base) Tel forth youre tale / leeue maister deere
(base) Here endeth the prolog

div.l: (base) Whilom / ther was dwellynge in my contree
(base) An Erchedekne / a man of hy degree
(base) That boldely / dide execucioun
(base) In punysshynge of Fornicacioun
(base) Of wicchecraft and eek of Bawderye
(base) Of diffamacioun / and auoutrye
(base) Of chirche Reues / and of testamentz
(base) Of contractes / and eek of lakke of sacramentz
(base) Of vsure / and of Symonye also
(base) But certes / lecchours / dide he grettest wo
(base) They sholde syngen if that they were hent
(base) And smale tytheres were foule yschent
(base) If any persoun / wold vpon hem pleyne
(base) Ther myghte asterte hym no pecunial peyne
(base) For smale tithes and for smal offryng
(base) He made the peple ful pitusly to syng
(base) For er the bysschop caght hem with hys hooc
(base) They were in the erchdeknys book /
(base) And thanne had he thurgh hys Iurisdiccion
(base) Power to do on hem correccion
(base) He hadde a Somnour / redy to his hond
(base) A slyer boy / nas noon in Engelond
(base) For subtilly / he hadde his espiaille
(base) That taughte hym / wher hym myghte auaille
(base) He koude spare / of lecchours / oon or two
(base) To techen hym / to foure and twenty mo
(base) For theigh this Somnour / wood were as an hare
(base) To telle his harlotrye / I wol nat spare
(base) For we been / out of his correccioun
(base) They han of vs / no Iurisdiccioun
(base) Ne neuere shullen / terme of hir lyues
(base) ¶ Peter / so been wommen of the Styves
(base) Quod the Somnour / yput out of my cure
(base) ¶ Pees with myschaunce / and with mysauenture
(base) Thus seyde oure hoost / and lat hym telle his tale
(base) Now telleth forth / thogh that the Somnour gale
(base) Ne spareth nat myn owene mayster deere
(base) ¶ This false theef this Somnour / quod the frere
(base) Hadde alwey / baudes redy to his hond
(base) As any hauk to lure in Engelond
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That tolde hym / al the secree that they knewe
(base) For hire aqueyntance / was nat come of newe
(base) They weren / hise Approwours pryuely
(base) He took hymself / a greet profit ther by
(base) His maister knew nat alwey / what he wan
(base) Withouten mandement a lewed man
(base) He koude somne / on peyne of cristes curs
(base) And they were glade / for to fille his purs
(base) And make hym / grete festes atte nale
(base) And right as Iudas / hadde purses smale
(base) And was a theef right swich a theef was he
(base) His maister / hadde but half his duetee
(base) He was / if I shal yeuen hym his laude
(base) A theef / and eek a somnour / and a baude
(base) He hadde eek wenches / at his retenue
(base) That wheither that sir Robert / or sire hewe
(base) Or Iakke / or Rauf or who so that it were
(base) That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
(base) Thus was the wenche and he / of oon assent
(base) And he wolde fecche / a feyned mandement
(base) And somne hem to Chapitre / bothe two
(base) And pile the man / and lete the wenche go
(base) ¶ Thanne wolde he seye / freend I shal for thy sake
(base) Do stryke hire / out of oure lettres blake
(base) Thee thar namoore / as in this cas trauaille
(base) I am thy freend / ther I thee may auaille
(base) Certeyn / he knew of bryberyes mo
(base) Than possible is / to telle in yeres two
(base) For in this world / nys dogge for the bowe
(base) That kan an hurt deer / from an hool knowe
(base) Bet than this somnour / knew a sly lecchour
(base) Or an Auouter / or a paramour
(base) And for that was / the fruyt of al his rente
(base) Therfore on it / he sette al his entente
(base) ¶ And so bifel / that ones on a day
(base) This Somnour / euere waityng on his pray
(base) For to somne an old wydewe / a Ribibe
(base) Feynynge a cause / for he wolde brybe
(base) Happed / that he say / bifore hym ryde
(base) A gay yeman / vnder a Forest syde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) A bowe he bar / and arwes brighte and kene
(base) He hadde vpon / a courtepy of grene
(base) An hat vpon his heed / with frenges blake
(base) ¶ Sire quod this Somnour / hayl / and wel atake
(base) ¶ Wel come quod he / and euery good felawe
(base) Where ridestow / vnder this grene shawe
(base) Seyde this yeman / wiltow fer to day
(base) ¶ This Somnour hym answerde / and seyde nay
(base) Here faste by quod he / is myn entente
(base) To ryden / for to reysen vp a rente
(base) That longeth / to my lordes duetee
(base) ¶ Artow thanne a Bailly ; / ye quod he
(base) He dorste nat for verray filthe and shame
(base) Seye that he was a Somnour / for the name
(base) ¶ Depardieux quod this yeman / deere brother
(base) Thow art a bailly / and I am another
(base) I am vnknowen / as in this contree
(base) Of thyn aqueyntance / I wolde praye thee
(base) And eek of bretherhede / if that yow leste
(base) I haue gold / and siluer in my cheste
(base) ¶ If that thee happed / to come in oure shire
(base) Al shal be thyn / right as thow wolt desire
(base) ¶ Graunt mercy quod this Somnour / by my feith
(base) Euerich in ootheres hond / his trouthe leyth
(base) For to be sworn bretheren / til they deye
(base) In daliaunce / they ryden forth and pleye
(base) ¶ This Somnour / which that was / as ful of Iangles
(base) As ful of venym / been thise waryangles
(base) And euere enqueryng vpon euery thyng
(base) Brother quod he / where is now youre dwellyng
(base) Another day / if that I sholde yow seche
(base) This yeman hym answerde / in softe speche
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / fer in the North contree
(base) Where as I hope / som tyme I shal thee see
(base) Er we departe / I shal thee so wel wisse
(base) That of myn hous / ne shaltow neuere mysse
(base) ¶ Now brother quod this Somnour / I yow preye
(base) Teche me / whil that we ryden by the weye
(base) Syn that ye been a Baillyf / as am I
(base) Som subtiltee / and tel me feithfully
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In myn office / how I may moost wynne
(base) And spareth nat for conscience ne synne
(base) But as my brother / tel me how do ye
(base) ¶ Now by my trouthe / brother deere / seyde he
(base) As I shal tellen thee / a feithful tale
(base) My wages been / ful streyte / and ful smale
(base) My lord is hard to me / and daungerous
(base) And myn office / is ful laborous
(base) And therfore / by extorcions I lyue
(base) For sothe I take / al that men wol me yeue
(base) Algate / by sleighte / or by violence
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / I wynne al my dispence
(base) I kan no bettre tellen / feithfully
(base) ¶ Now certes quod this Somnour / so fare I
(base) I spare nat to taken / god it woot
(base) But it be to heuy / or to hoot
(base) What I may gete / in conseil priuely
(base) No manere conscience / of that haue I
(base) Nere myn extorcioun / I myghte nat lyuen
(base) Ne of swiche Iapes / wol I nat be shryuen
(base) Stomak ne Conscience / ne knowe I noon
(base) I sherewe / thise Shryftesfadres euerychon
(base) Wel be we met by god / and by seint Iame
(base) But leeue brother / tel me thanne thy name
(base) Quod this Somnour / in this mene whyle
(base) This yeman / gan a litel for to smyle
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / woltow that I thee telle
(base) I am a feend / my dwellyng is in helle
(base) And here I ryde / aboute my purchasyng
(base) To wite / wher men wolde yeue me any thyng
(base) My purchas / is theffect of al my rente
(base) Looke how thow rydest for the same entente
(base) To wynne good / thow rekkest neuere how
(base) Right so fare I / for ryde wold I now
(base) Vnto the worldes ende / for a preye
(base) ¶ A quod this Somnour / benedicite what sey ye
(base) I wende / ye were a yeman trewely
(base) Ye han a mannes shap / as wel as I
(base) Han ye a figure thanne / determynat
(base) In helle ther ye been / in youre estat
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Nay certeynly quod he / ther haue we noon
(base) But whan vs liketh / we kan take vs oon
(base) Or ellis make yow seme / we ben shape
(base) Som tyme / lyk a man / or lyk an Ape
(base) Or lyk an Aungel / kan I ryde or go
(base) It is no wonder thyng theigh it be so
(base) A lousy Iogelour / kan deceyue thee
(base) And pardee yet kan I / moore craft than he
(base) ¶ Whi quod this Somnour / ryde ye thanne or goon
(base) In sondry shap / and nat alwey in oon
(base) ¶ For we quod he / wol vs swiche formes make
(base) As moost able is / oure preyes for to take
(base) ¶ What maketh yow / to han al this labour
(base) ¶ Ful many a cause / leue sire Somnour
(base) Seyde this feend / but alle thyng hath tyme
(base) The day is short / and it is passed pryme
(base) And yet ne wan I no thyng in this day
(base) I wol entende / to wynnyng if I may
(base) And nat entende / oure wittes to declare
(base) For brother myn / thy wit is al to bare
(base) To vnderstonde / althogh I tolde hem thee
(base) But for thow axest why labouren we
(base) For som tyme / we been goddes Instrumentz
(base) And meenes / to doon his comandementz
(base) Whan that hym list / vpon his creatures
(base) In diuers art and in diuerse figures
(base) Withouten hym / we han no myght certayn
(base) If that hym lyst to stonde ther agayn
(base) And som tyme / at oure preyere / han we leue
(base) Oonly the body / and nat the soule greue
(base) Witnesse on Iob / whom that we diden wo
(base) And som tyme / han we myght of bothe two
(base) This is to seyn / of soule and body eke
(base) And som tyme / be we suffred for to seke
(base) Vpon a man / and do his soule vnreste
(base) And nat his body / and al is for the beste
(base) Whan he with standeth / oure temptacioun
(base) It is / a cause / of his sauacioun
(base) Al be it that it was / nat oure entente
(base) He sholde be sauf but that we wolde hym hente
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And somtyme / be we seruant vnto man
(base) As to the Erchebisshop / Seint Dunstan
(base) And to the Apostles / seruant eek was I
(base) ¶ Yet tel me / quod the Somnour feithfully
(base) Make ye yow newe bodyes / thus alway
(base) Of Elementz / the feend answerde nay
(base) Som tyme we feyne / and som tyme we aryse
(base) With dede bodyes / in ful sondry wyse
(base) And speke as renably / and faire and wel
(base) As to the Phitonissa / dide Samuel
(base) And yet wol som men seye / it was nat he
(base) I do no fors / of youre dyuynytee
(base) But o thyng warne I thee / I wol nat Iape
(base) Thow wolt algates wite / how we be shape
(base) Thow shalt her afterwardes / my brother deere
(base) Come there / thee nedeth nat of me to lere
(base) For thow shalt by thyn owene experience
(base) Konne in a chayer / rede of this sentence
(base) Bet than Virgile / whil he was on lyue
(base) Or Dant also / now lat vs ryde blyue

I me reioysed of my liberte
Þat selde tyme is founden in mariage
Þer y was free y mote ben in ꝸseruage
¶ But natheles y se youre trew entente
And trust vpon youre wit and have don ay
Where fore of my fre wille y wol assent
To wedde as sone as ever y may
But þer as ye han ꝓprofered me to day
To chese me a wife y you relese
That choyse ⁊ prey you of þat profer cesse
¶ For god it wote þat children of byn
Vnlike hir worthi eldres hem byfore
Bontee comyth al of god not of þe strene
Of which þey byn engendred and y bore
I trust in goddes bonte and þer fore
My mariage and myn estate and reste
I hym bytake he may don as him leste
¶ Let me allone in chesyng of my wyfe
Þat charge vpon my bak y wol endure
But y you prey and charge vpon youre lyf
What wyfe þat y take ye me ensure
To worship hir while þat hir lyfe may dure
In worde and werk boþe here and every where
As sheo an Emperoures doughter were
¶ And furthermore þis shal ye swere þat ye
Agayn my choys shul never grucche ne stryve
For sith y shal for go my liberte
At youre request as ever mote y thryve
Ther as myn hert is sette þer wol y wyve
And but ye wol assent in such manere
I prey you speketh na more of þis matere
¶ With hertely wille þey sworn and assenten
To al þis þing þer seyde no wyght nay
Bysekyng him of grace or þat þey wenten
Þat he wolde graunten hem a certeyn day
Of his spousaille as sone as ever he may
For yet alwey somwhat þe peple drad
Lest þat þe Markys no wyfe wolde wedde
¶ He graunted hem aday such as him liste
On which he wold be wedded sikerly
And seid he dede al þis at hir requeste
And they with humble entent buxumly
Knelyng on hir knees reuerently
Him thonken alle and þus þey have an ende

¶ And her vpon he to his officers
Commaundeth for þe fest to purvey
And to his pryve knyghtis and squyers

And þei to his cōmmaundement obey

et hic incipit pars secunda

¶ Amonges þis poure folke þer dwelt aman

Ianicula men of þat þropēm him calle

¶ But forto speke of vertuous beautee
Thanne was she oon þe feirest vnder sonne
For poverlich y fostered vp was shoe
No likerous lust was þorogh hir hert y ronne
Wel ofter of þe welle þan of þe tonne
She dronk and for she wolde vertew plese
She knew laboure but noon ydel ease
¶ But þough þis mayde tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of hir virginite
Þer was enclosed rype and sadde corage
And in grete reverence and cherite
Hir olde pover fader fostered she
A fewe sheep on felde spynnyng she kepte
She woldnot byn ydel tyl she slepte
¶ And whan she hamward came she wolde brynge
Wortes or other herbes tymes ofte
Þe which she shredde ⁊ seeth for her leuynge
And made her bedde ful herde and noþyng softe
And ay she kepte hir faderes lyfe and ofte

¶ Vpon Griselde þis pover creature
Ful ofte sithes þis Markys sette his Ie
As he an hontyng rode ꝑperaventure

¶ Commendyng in his hert hir wommanhede
And eke hir vertew passyng any wight
Of so yonge age as wel in chere as dede
For þough þe peple hedde no grete in sight
In vertu he considered ful right
Hir bounte and disposed þat he wolde
Wedde hir only yf ever he wedde shulde
¶ The day of weddyng cam but no wight kan
Tel what womman hit shulde be
For which mervayle wondered many aman
And seiden when þey were in pryvete
Wolnot oure lorde yet leve his vanite
Wol he not wedde allas þe while
Whi wol he þus him selfe and vs by gile
¶ But natheles þis Markis hath don make
Of gemmys sette in gold and in asure
Broches and rynges for griseldes sake
And of hir cloþing tooke he þe mesure
Of a mayde like to hir stature
And eke of other ournaments alle
That onto suche a weddyng shulde falle
¶ Þe tyme of vndren of þe same day
Approcheth þat þis weddyng shulde be
And alle þe paleys put was in arraye
Both halle and Chambres ech in his degre
Houses of office stuffed with plente
Ther maistow se of dentevous vitaille
Þat may be founde as ferre as lasteth ytaille
¶ Þis rial Markis richely arrayed
Lordys and ladies in his compaignye
The which to þe feste were y preyed
And of his retynew þe bachillerye
With many a soun of sundry melodye
Vnto þe village of which of which y tolde
In þis array þe right wey han holde
¶ Grisel of þis god wote ful Innocent
Þat for hir shapen was al hir array

And cometh home as sone as ever she may
For wel she hedde harde at þat day
Þe Markys shulde wedde ⁊ if she myght
She wolde fayn have seyn sōmme of þat sight
¶ She thought y wol with other maydyns stonde
Þat byn my felawes in oure dore and se
Þe markys and þerfore wol y founde
To don at home as soune as it may be
The laboure which þat longeth vnto me
And þenne y may at leyser hir biholde
Yf she þis wey vnto þe castel holde
¶ And as she wolde ouer hir thresshfold gon
Þe Markys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water potte anon
Beside þe þresshfold in an oxe stalle
And dow vpon hir knees she gan to falle
With ful sadde contenaunce kneleth stille
Tille she hedde harde hir lordys wylle
¶ Þe þoghtfull Markys spake vnto þis mayde
Ful soberly and seyde in þis manere
Wher is youre fader o Griseldes he seide
And she with reverence in humble chere
Answered lord he is al redy here
And In she goth withouten lenger lette
And to þe Markys she hir fader fette
¶ He by þe honde þenne toke þis olde man
And seide þis whēm he him hedde aside
Ienycula y neither may ne kan
Lenger þe plesaunce of myn hert hide
Yf þat þou vouchesafe bityde what bytyde
Thi dougthter wol y take er y wende
As for my wyfe vnto my lyves ende
¶ Þou lovest me y wot hit wel certeyn
And art my feithful liegeman ybore
And al þat lyketh me y dar wel seyn
It liketh þe and specially therfore
Tel me þat point þat y have seide byfore
If þat þou wolt vnto þat purpos drawe
To make me as for þi sonne in lawe
¶ Þe sodeyn cas þis man astonyed was so
Þat rede he waxt abassched and al quakyng
He stode vnnethes seide he wordes mo
But only thus lord qd he my willyng
Is as ye wole ne ayeins youre lykyng
I wol no þing ye be my lorde so dere
Right as you lest governeth þis matere
¶ Yt wol y qd þis Markys softely
Þat in þy chaumbre y and þow and she
Have a collacion and wost þou why
For I wol axe if it hir wyl be
To be my wyf and rewle hir after me
And al þis shal be don in þy presence
I wol not speke oute of þyn audience
¶ And in the chambre while þey were aboute
Hir tretys which þat ye schul after here
Þe peple cam into þe hous withoute
And wondered hem in how honest manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader dere
But outerly Griseldis wonder myȝt
For never eft sawe she such a sight
¶ No wonder ys þough she ys astonyed
To seen so grete a gist comyn in þat place
She never was to such gestes woned
For which she loked with ful pale a face
But shortely forth þis matere forto chace
Þese arn þe wordes þat þe markys seide
To þis benygne verray feithful mayde
¶ Griselde he seid ye shal wel vnderstonde
It liketh to youre fader and to me
Þat y you wedde and eke it may so stonde
As y suppose ye wol þat it so be
But this demaundes axe y first qd he
Þat sith hit shal be doun in hastyf wyse
Wol ye assent or ellis you avyse
¶ I sey as þus be ye redy fully wyth gode hert
To al my lust and þat y frely may
As me best þinketh do ye laughte or smerte
And never ye to grocche it nyght nor day
And eke when I sey ye ne sey nought nay
Neither by worde ne frownyng contenaunce
Svere þis and I swere you here alliaunce
¶ Wondryng vpon þis word quakyng for drede
She seide lord vndigne and vnworthi
I am to þilke honoure þat ye me bede
But as ye wol youre selfe right so wol I
And here I swere þat never wyllyngly
In werke ne þought nyl I you disobey
For to be dede þogh me were loth to dey
¶ This is y nogh greselde myn qd he
And forth he goth with aful sobre chere
Oute at the dore and after cam she
And to þe peple he seide in þis manere
Þis is my wif qd he þat stondeth here
Honoureth hir and loveth hir y prey
Who so me loveth þer nys namore to sey
¶ And forþat no thing of hir olde gere
She shulde brynge in to his hous he bedde
Þat wymme shulde dispoilen hir right þere
Of which þese ladies were noȝt right gladde
To handel hir cloþes where yn she was cladde
But natheles þis mayde bright of hew
Fro fote to hede þey clothed han al newe
¶ Hir heris han þey kembed þat lay vntrassed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngeres smale
A Corone on her hed han þey dressed
And sette hir ful of nouches grete and smale
Of hir array what shulde y telle a tale
Vnneth þe peple hir knew for hir feirenesse
When she translated was in such richesse
¶ This Markis hath hir spoused with a rynge
Broght for þe same cause and þen hir sette
Vpon an hors snowe white and wel ambelyng
And to his paleys er he longer lette
With Ioyful peple þat hir ladde and mette
Conuoyed hir and þus þe day þey spende
In revel tyl þe sonne gan discende
¶ And shortly forth þis tale forto chace
I sey þat to þis new merkysesse
God hath such fauour sent hir of his grace
Þat it ne semed not by lykenesse
Þat she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in A Cote or in an oxe stalle
But norisched in an Emperoures halle
¶ To every wight she waxen is so dere
And worshupful þat folk þer she was bore
And from hir birth knewe hir yere by yere
Vnneth trowed þey but durst han swore
Þat to Ianicle of which y spake to fore
She doghter were for as by coniecture
Hem þought she was another creature
¶ For þogh that euer vertuous was she
She was encresed in such excellence
Of thewes gode yset in high bounte
And so discrete and faire of eloquence
So benigne and so digne of reverence
And cowde so the peples hertes enbrace
That yche hir loveth þat loketh in hir face
¶ Nought oonly of saluces in þe towne
Puplissched was þe beaute of hir name
But eke biside in every regiou
If oon seyde wel another seide þe same
So spradde of hir high bounte þe name
Þat men and wymmen as wel yonge as olde
Gon to saluce vpon hir to be holde
¶ This Walter lowly nay but rially
Wedded with fortune honeste
In goddes pes lyueth ful esyly
At home and outeward garace ynogh hed he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degre
Was of vertew hid þat peple him hilde
A prudent man and that ys seien ful selde
¶ Not oonly þis Griseldis þorogh hir wit
Koude al þe fete of wyfly humblenesse
But eke when þat þe cas required it
Þe commune profite coude she redresse
Ther nas discorde rancour ne hevynesse
In al þat land þat she ne koude apayse
And wisely bryng hem all in rest and eayse
¶ Þogh þat hir housbonde absent were anon
If gentlemen or other of hir contre
Were wroth she wolde bryngen hem atone
So wise and rype wordes hedde she
And Iuggementys of so grete equyte
Þat she from heven sent was as men wende
Peple to save and every wrong tamende
¶ Nat longe tyme after þat Grisilde
Was wedded sheo a doughter hath ybore
hedde hir lever born a knave chylde
Glad was the Markis and the folke þer fore
For þough a maide childe come al byfore
She may vnto a knave childe atteyne
By likelyhede seyn she nys not bareyne

⁊ þogh to me þat ye be leef and dere

¶ And namely sith þi doghter was y bore

But y desire as y have don by fore

¶ And yet god wote þis is ful loth to me

¶ Glad was þis Markis of hir answerynge

Þat lordes hestes mownot byn yfeyned

¶ Þis childe y am cōmmaunded for to take

¶ Suspecious was þe diffame of þes man

¶ But at the last to speken she bygan

¶ And þus she seide in hir benygne voyce

¶ Þis sergeant cam vnto his lorde agayn

¶ And bade his sergeant þat he shulde pryuely

Ne when he came ne wheder he wente
¶ But at Boloyne he to his sistre dere
Þat þilke tyme of payuyk was countesse

¶ Þe sergeant goth and hath fulfilled þis þynge

¶ As glad as humble as besy in seruyse
And eke in love as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in every maner wyse
Ne of hir doughter noȝt a worde spake she

Was seyn in hir ne never hir doughter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
