In þis estate þer passed byn foure yere
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knave childe she bar by þis Walter
Ful gracious and feire for to be holde
And whan þat folke it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contrey mery
Was for þis childe and god þei þonke and hery
¶ Whan It was two yere olde and fro þe breste
Departed fro his norice on a day
Þis Markys cautht yet another leste
To tempte his wif yet ofter yf he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne know no mesure
When þat þey fynde apacient creature
¶ Wif qd þis markis ye han herde er þis
My peple sykely bereth oure mariage
And namely sith my sone yborne is
Now is it worse þan euꝰer in al oure age
Þe murmur sleeth myn hert and my corage

¶ Nou sey þey þus when walter ys agon
Thanne shal þe blode of Ianicle succede
And byn oure lorde for other have we non
Such wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of such murmur taken hede
For certeynly y drede such sentence
Þogh þey not pleyn speke in myn Audience
¶ I wolde lyve in pees if y myght
Wherfore y am disposed outerly
As I his sustre ꝸserued by nyght
Right so thinke y to ꝸserve him preveyly
Þis warne y you þat ye not sodeynly

¶ I have qd he seyde þus and ever shal
I wol no þing ne nyl no thing certeyne
But as þow lust þing greueth me at al
Þogh þat my doughter and my sone byn slayn
At youre commaundement þis is to seyn
I have hedde no part of children tweyn
But first sykenesse and after wo and peyn .
¶ Ye ben oure lorde do with youre owne þing
Right as you lust axeth no rede at me
For as y lefte at home al my clothing
When y first cam to you right so qd she
Lefte y my wille and alle my liberte
And toke youre clothing wherfore y you preye
Doth youre plesaunce y wol youre lust obeye
¶ And certys if y hedde prescience
Youre wille to know yer ye youre luste to me tolde
I wolde it don withouten necligence
But now y wote youre lust and what ye wolde
Al youre plesaunce ferme and stable I holde
For wist y þat my deth wolde do yow ease
Right gladly wold y dyen you to plese
¶ Deth may noght make no comparisou
Vnto youre love and whan þis markis say
Þe constance of his wif he cast a down
His eyen two and wondereth þat she may
In pacience suffre al þis array
And forth he goth with drery contenaunce
But to his hert it was ful grete plesaunce
¶ Þis vgle sergeaunt in þe same wyse
Þat he hir doughter caughte right so he
Or worse yf men kan devyse
Hath hent hir sone þat ful was of beawte
And euer in oon so pacient was she
Þat she no chere made of hevynesse
But kyst hir sone and after gan it blesse
¶ Save þis she preyed him þat if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erþe grave
His tendre lymes delicat to sight
Fro foules and bestes it to save
But she non answere of him myght have
He went his wey as him no þing ne routh
But to Boleyne he tendrely it broȝt
¶ Þis Markis wondꝰereth eveꝰer lengeꝰer þe more
Vpon hir pacience and yf þat she
Ne hedde sothly knowen byfore
Þat ꝑperfitely hir children loved she
He wolde have wende þat som subtelte
And of malice or for crewel corage
Þat she hedde suffered þis with sadde visage
¶ But wel he knew þat next him selfe certeyne
She loued hir children best in every wyse
But now of wommen wolde y axen fayn
If þis assaies myghtnat suffise
What coude a stordy housbonde more devyse
To prove hir wifhode and hir stedefastnesse
And he contynuyng []euereuer in sturdynesse
¶ But þer byn folke of suche condicou
Þat when þey have acerteyn purpos take
Þey kannot stynt of hir entencion
But right as þey were bounden to þat stake
Þey wolnot of þat first purpos slake
Right so this Markis fully hath purposed
To tempte his wif as he was first disposed
¶ He wayteth if by worde or contenaunce
That she to him was changed of corage
But never cowde he fynde variaunce
She was ay oon in hert and in visage
And ay þe forther þat she was in age
The more trew if þat it were possible
She was to him in love ay more panyble
¶ For which it semed þus þat of hem two
Þer was but o will as Walter liste
Þe same lust was hir plesance also
And god be þenked al fil for þe beste
She shewed welle þat for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of her selue no þing ne shulde
Wylle no þing but as hir housbonde wolde
¶ Þe schaundre of Walter ofte and wide spradde
That of a Cruel hart he wikkedly
For he apore womman wedded hadde
Hath mordered bothe his children pryveyly
Suchmurmur was among hem comumly
No wonder is forto þe peples ere
Þer cam no worde out þat þey mordred were
¶ For which þer as his peple þer before
Hedde loved hem well þe sclaundre of his diffame
Made hem þat þey him hated þerfore
To byn a mordrer is a hateful name
But neþeles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wyf was sette al his entente
¶ Whan þat his doghter xij yere was of age
He to þe court of Rome in subtel wyse
Enfourmed of his wille sent his message
Commaundyng hem such bulles to devyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
How þat þe pope as for his peples reste
Bade hem to wedde another if hem luste
¶ I sey he bade þey shulde counterfete
Þe popes bulles makyng mensiou
Þat he hath leve his furst wife to lete
As by þe popes dispensaciou
To stynt rauncour and distenciou
Bitwixt his peple and him þus seith þe bulle
Þe which þey han puplesshed atte fulle
¶ The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden ful wel þat hit hedde byn right so
But whan þis tydynges came to Griseldis
I deme þat hir herte was ful wo
But she ylike sadde for euermo
Disposed was þis humble creature
Þe aduersite of fortune al tendure
¶ Abidyng ever his lust and his plesaunce
To whom þat she was yeven herte and al
As to hir verray worldes suffisaunce
But shortly if y þis story tellen shal
This Markis wreten hath in special
A letter in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to boleyn hit sent
¶ To þe Erle of Panyk which þat hedde þo
Wedded his suster preyed he specially
To bryngyn home a gayn hhishis children two
In honourable estate and openly
But o thing he him preyed outerly
Þat he to no wight þough men wolde enquere
Shulde not telle whos children þat þey were
¶ But sey þe mayden shulde y wedded be
Vnto þe Markys of saluce anon
And as þis Erle was preyed so dede he
For at þe day set he is on his wey gon
Toward saluce and lordes many oon
In rich array þis mayden forto guyde
Hir yong brother rydyng hir byside
¶ Arrayed was toward hir mariage
Þis fressh mayde ful of gemmys clere
Hir brother which þat vij yere was of age
Arrayed eke ful fressh in his manere
And thus with grete noblenesse and glad chere
Toward saluces shapyng hir Iourney
Fro day to day þey ryden in hir wey

Here endeth the fourth parte .
And begynneth the fyfe parte
Among al þis after his wikke vsage
Þis Markis yet his wif to tempte more
To þe outrest prevey of hir corage
Fully to han experience and lore
If þat she were as stedefast as byfore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystersly hath seide hir þis sentence
¶ Certis Gresilde y hedde y nogh plesance
To haue you to my wyfe for youre godnesse
As for youre trouth and youre obeysance
Noght for youre linage ne for youre richesse
But now knowe y in verray sothfastnesse
Þat in grete lorshup If I wolde avyse
Þer is grete ꝸseruytute in sondry wyse
¶ I may noght do as every ploghman may
My peple me contreineth for to take
Another wif and crien day by day
And eke þe pope rancour for to slake
Concenteth it þat dar y vndertake
And trewly þus much y wol you sey
My new wyfe ys comyng by þe wey
¶ Be stronge of hert and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower þat ye broghten me
Take it agayn y graunt it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous qd he
No man may alwey han prosꝑperite
With euen hert y rede you tendure
Þe stroke of fortune or of aventure
¶ And she agayn answered in pacience
My lorde qd she y wot and wist alwey
How þat bi twixt youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Make comparison it is no nay
I ne hilde me never digne in no maner
To be youre wyfe no ne youre chambrere
¶ And in this hous þer ye me lady made
Þe high god take y for my wittenesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I never helde me lady ne maistrasse
But homble ꝸseruant to youre worthinesse
And ever shal while þat my lyfe may dure
Aboven every worldely creature
¶ Þat ye so longe of youre benignite
Han holden me in honoure and nobeley
Wher as y was noȝt worthi for to be
Þat thonke I god and you to whom I prey
Foryelde it you þer is namore to sey
Vnto my fader gladly wol y wende
And with hym dwelle vnto my lyves ende
¶ Þer y was fostered of a childe ful smal
Tyl y be dede my lyfe þer wol y lede
A wedewe clene in body hert and al
For sith y yaf to you my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyfe it is no drede
God sheld such alordes wyf to take
Another man to housbonde or to make
¶ And of youre new wif god of his grace
So graunt you welth and prosꝑperite
For y wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which þat I was blisful wonte to be
For sith it liketh you my lord qd shee
Þat whilome weren al myn hertes reste
Þat I shal gon y wol go when you leste
¶ But ther as ye me profre such dowaire
As I first broght it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no þyng faire
The which to me were harde nowe forto fynde
O goode god how gentile and how kynde
Ye semed by youre spech and youre visage
Þat day þat maked was oure mariage
¶ But soth is seyde algate y fynde it trewe
For in effecte y preved is on me
Love is noght olde as whan þat it is newe
But certys lorde for non aduersite
To dyen in þis cas it shal not bee
Þat ever in worde or werke y shal repente
Þat I you yaf myn herte in hole entente
¶ My lorde ye wote þat in my fadres place
Ye dede me strepe oute of my pouere wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To you broght y noȝt ellys oute of drede
But feith and mekenesse and maydynhede
And here agayn my cloþing y restore
And eke my weddyng ryng for evermore
¶ The remaunt of youre yuyls redy be
With In youre chambre dar I safly seyn
Naked oute of my fadres hous qd sle
I com and naked mote y turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folowen fayn
But yet y hope it be not youre entente
That I smokkeles oute of youre paleys went
¶ Ye koude not do so dishonest athing
Þat þilke wombe in which youre children lay
Shulde be fore þe peple in my walkyng
Be seyn alle bare where fore y you prey
Let me not like a worme go by þe wey
Remembre you my owne lorde so dere
I was youre wif þough y vnworthi were
¶ Where fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which þat y broght and noght agayn ybere
As voucheth saufe to yeve me to my mede
But such a smok as y were wont to were
Þat y ther with may wrye the wombe of here
Þat was youre wyfe and here take y my leve
Of you myn owne lorde lest y you greve
¶ The smok qd he þat þou hast on þy bak
Let it be stille and bere it forth with þe
But wel vnnethes þilke worde spake he spak
But went his wey for rewth and for petee
By forn þe folke her selven strepeth she
And in her smok with hede and fete al bare
Towarde hir fader house forth is she fare
¶ Þe folke hir folowen weping in hir wey
And fortune ay þey cursen as þey gon
But she fro weping kept her yen dry
Ne in this tyme worde ne spake she non
Here fader þat þis tyding herde anon
Curseth þe day and tyme of nature
Shoopēm him to byn alyves creature
¶ For oute of doute þis olde pore man
Was ever in suspecte of hir mariage
For ever he demeth sith þat it bygan
Þat when þe lorde fulfylled hedde his corage
Hym wolde thinke it were a disꝑperage
To his estate so lowe forto alyȝt
And voyden her as sone as he myȝt
¶ A gayns his doughter hastilich goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew her comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myght be
He couered her ful routhfully wepynge
But on hir body myȝt he it not brynge
For rude was þe cloth and sheo more of age
By dayes fele þan at hir mariage
¶ Þus with hir fader for a certeyn space
Dwelleth þis floure of wifly paciens
That neither by hir wordes ne hir face
Byforn þe folke ne in hir absence
Ne shewed she þat hir was don offence
Ne of hir high estate no remembraunce
Ne hadde she as by hir contenaunce
¶ No wonder is for in hir grete estate
Hir gost was ever in playn humilite
No tendre mouth non hert delicate
No pompe no semblant of rialte
But ful of pacient benignyte
Discrete and prideles ay honourable
And to hir housbonde ay meke and stable
¶ Men speke of Iob and most for his humblesse
As clerkys when hem leste kan welle endite
Namely of men but as in sothfastnesse
Though clerkis preyse wymmen but alyte
Þer kan no man in humblenesse hem acquyte
As wymmen kan ne kan be halfe so trewe
As wymmen ben but it be fals of newe
¶ Fro boloygne is þis Erle of Paynyk come
Of which þe fame vp sprraonge to more and lesse
And to þe peples erys al and some
Was couth þat a newe merkesesse
He with him broght in such pomp and richesse
That never was þer seyn with mannys Iye
So noble array in all westlumbardye
¶ The Markis which þat shope and knew al þis
Er þat þis Erle was come sent his message
For þilke sely pore Greseldys
And she with humble hert and glad visage
Nat with no swollen þought in hir corage
Came at his hest and on hir knees hir sette
And reverently and wisely she him grette
¶ Grisilde qd he my wil is outerly
Þis maiden þat wedded shal he vnto me
Receyved be to morowe as rially
And it is in myn house to be
And eke þat every wyght in his degre
Have his estate in sittyng and ꝸseruice
And high plesence as I kan best devyse
¶ I have no womman suffisant certeyn
Þe chambres for to array in ordynaunce
After my lust and therfore wolde I fayne
Þat þyn were al such maner gouernaunce
Þou knowest eke of olde al my plesance
Þogh þin array be badde and evel be sey
Do þou thi devoure at the lest wey
¶ Not oonly lorde þat y am glad qd she
To doon youre luste but I desire also
Youe for to ꝸserue and plese in myn degre
Withouten feyntyng and shal evermo
Ne never for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal þe gost with Inne myn hert stynte
To love you best with al my trewe entente
¶ And with þat worde she gan þe hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to don al þat she myȝt
Preyeng þe chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she most ꝸseruisable of alle
Hath euꝰery chambre arrayed and his halle
¶ Abowte vndern gan þis Erle alighte
Þat wtith hym broȝt þis noble children tweye
For which þe peple ran to se þat sight
Of hir array so rychely beseye
And thanne at erste amonges hem they seye
Þat Walter was no fole þough þat him leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for þe beste
¶ For she is fairer as þey demen alle
Þan is Greselde and more tendre of age
And feirer fruyte bytwene hem shulde falle
And more plesant for hir high lynage
Hir brother eke so feire was of visage
Þat hem to seen þe peple hath cauth plesaunce
Commendyng now þe markys gouernaunce
¶ O stormy peple vnsadde and ever vntrewe
Ay vndiscrete and chaūngynge as a vane
Deliteyng ever in roumbel þat is newe
For like þe mone ay waxe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng dere y nogh a Iane
Youre dome is fals youre custaunce yuel preveth
A ful grete foole is he þat on you lyveth
¶ Þus seyden sadde folke in þat Citee
When þat þe peple gazed vp and down
For þey were gladde right for þe noveltee
To have anew lady of þat town
Namore of þis make y now mensiou
But to Griselde agay y wol me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir besynesse
¶ Ful besy was Greselde in every thinge
Þat to þe fest was aꝑpertinente
Right noght was she abaisched of hir clothing
Þogh it were rude and somdel eke to rente
But with glad chere vnto þe yaate is she wente
With other folke to grete þe Merkysesse
And after þat doth forth hir bysynesse
¶ With so glad chere his gestes she resceyveth
And so konnyngly everich in his degre
That no defaute no man aꝑperceyveth
But ay they wonderen what she myȝt be
Þat in so pore array was forto se
And koude such honoure and reverence
And worthily þey preysen hir prudence
¶ In al þis mene while she ne stynte
Þis mayde and eke hir brother to commende
With al hir hert in ful benygne entente
So wel þat no man koude hir prise amende
But at the laste whan þat þe lordes wende
To sitten down to mete he gan to calle
Griselde as she was besy in his halle
¶ Greselde qd he as it were in his pley
How liketh þe my wif and hir beaute
Right wel qd she and in gode feye
A feyrer saugh y never non þan she
I prey to god yeve hir prosꝑperite
And so hope I þat he wol to yow sende
Plesaunce y nough vnto youre lyves ende
¶ O thing beseke y yow and warne also
Þat ye ne pryke with no turmentyng
This tendre mayden as ye have do mo
For she is fostered in hir norisshynge
More tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude not aduersite endure
As koude a pouere fostered creature
¶ And whan þis Walter saugh hir pacience
Hir glad chere and no malice at alle
And he so ofte hedde don to hir offence
And she ay hedde chere constant as a walle
Contenuyng euꝰer hir Innocence over alle
This stordy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen on hir wyfly stedefastnesse
¶ This is ynogh Greselde my qd he
Be now namore agast and evel apayed
And have yorur feith and youre benygnite
As welle as euꝰer womman was assayed
In grete astate and poverlich arrayed
Now know I dere wyf þi stedefastnesse
And hir in Armys toke and gan hir kisse
¶ And she for wonder tok of it no kepe
She herde not what þyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hedde sterte vp of a slepe
Tyl she of hir mazednesse abreyde
Greselde qd he by god þat for vs deyede
Þou arte my wyf ne non other I have
Ne never hadde as god my soule save
¶ This is þi doughter which þou hast supposed
To be my wyf þat other feithfully
Shal be myn eyre as I have ay supposed
Þou bare hem in þi body trewly
At Boloygne have I kepte hem preveyly
Take hem agayn for nowe maistow nat seye
Þat þou hast lorn non of þi children tweye
¶ Whan she this herde asownēm doun she falleth
For pitous Ioy and after hir sownyng
She both hir yonge children in to hir calleth
And In hir armes pitously vepyng
Embraseth hem and tenderly kyssyng
Ful like a moder with hir salt terys
She bathed both hir vysage and hir heres
¶ Of which apitous þing it was to se
Hir sownyng and hir humble voyce to here
Graunt mercy lorde god ythonke it you qd she
Þat ye han saved me my childrēmredere
Now rekke y never to byn dede right here
Sith y stonde in youre love and in youre grace
No force of deeth ne when my spirit pace
¶ O tendre o dere o yonge children myn
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
Þat creuel houndes or some foule vermyn
Hedde heten you but god of his mercy
And youre benigne fader tenderly
Hath don you kepte and in þat same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapt adown to grounde
¶ And in hir stogh so saddely holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tenbrace
Þat with grete sleith and grete difficulte
Þe children from hir arme gan to arrace
O many a tere o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem þat stoden hir biside
Vnneth aboute hir myght þey a byde
¶ Walter hir gladit and hir sorow slaketh
She riseth vp abaysshed from her traūnce
And euꝰery wight hir Ioy and fest maketh
Til she hath cauthe agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir doth so feithfully plesaunce
Þat it was deynte to seen þe chere
Be twixt hem two nowe þey byn met in fere
¶ These ladyes whan þey hir tyme say
Han taken hir and into chambre gon
And strepen hir out of hir rude array
And in a cloth of golde þat bright shone
With a coroune of mony a ryche stone
Vpon hir hede they in to halle hir brought
And ther she was honoured as hir oght
¶ Þus hath this pitous day ablisful ende
For euery man and womma doth his might
Þis day in mirth and revel to despende
Tyl on þe welken shone þe storres light
For more solempne in every mannes sight
This feste was than gretter of costage
Þan was þe revel of hir mariage
¶ Ful many a yere inful prosꝑperite
Lyven this two in concorde and in reste
And richely his doughter maried he
Vnto alorde oon of þe worthieste
Of alle ytaille and þen in pees and reste
His wyues fader in his court he kepeth
Tyl þat þe soule oute of þe body crepeth
¶ His sone succedit in his fadres heritage
In reste and pees after his faderes day
And fortunat was eke in mariage
Al pitte he nat his wyf in grete assay
Þis worlde is not so stronge it is no nay
As it hath byn in olde tymes yore
And herkeneth what þis auctor seyth þer fore
¶ Þis story is seyde not for wyues shulde
Folowen Grisilde as in humilite
For it were inportable þogh þey wolde
But for þat euery wight in his degre
Shulde be constant in aduersite
As was greselde þerfor Petrak writeth
Þis story which he with high style enditeth
¶ For sith a womma was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man wel more vs oughte
Receyven al in gree þat god vs sent
For grete skile is he preve þat he wroght
But he ne tempteth no man þat he boght
As seith seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preveth folke al wey it is no drede
¶ And suffereth vs as for oure excercite
With sharpe scorges of adversite
Ful ofte to byn bete in sondry wyse
Nat for to know oure wille for certes hee
Er we were born knew al oure freyeltee
And for oure beste is al his gouernaunce
Lete vs thenne lyve in vertuose sufferaunce
¶ But o word lordynges herkenneth er I go
It were ful harde to fynde now a dayes
In a town Greseldys thre or two
For if that they were putte to suche assayes
The golde of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras þat þogh the coyne be faire at Ie
It wol rather berst a two þan plye
¶ For which here for þe wyves love of Bath
Whos lyve and al hir secte god mentene
In high maistrye or elles were it scath
I wol with lusty herte fressch and grene
Sey you a songe to glade you I wene
And lete vs stynt of oure sighful matere
Herkeneth my songe þat seith in þis manere

(base) Thanne were we in heigh felicitee
(base) But trewely by daye it may nat be
(base) Men wolde seyn that we were theues stronge
(base) And for oure owene tresor doon vs honge
(base) This tresor moste ycaried be by nyghte
(base) As wisly and as sleyly as it myghte
(base) Therfore I rede that cut amonges vs alle
(base) Be drawe and lat se wher the cut wol falle
(base) And he that hath the cut with herte blithe
(base) Shal renne to towne and that ful swithe
(base) And brynge vs breed and wyn ful priuely
(base) And two of vs shal kepen subtilly
(base) This tresor wel and if he wol nat tarye
(base) Whan it is nyght we wol this tresor carye
(base) By oon assent wher as vs thynketh best
(base) That oon of hem the cut broghte in his fest
(base) And bad hem drawe and looke wher it wol falle
(base) And it fel on the yongeste of hem alle
(base) And forth toward the town he wente anon

div.l: (base) Thow knowest wel thow art my sworn brother
(base) Thy profit wol I telle thee anon
(base) Thow woost wel that oure felawe is agon
(base) And heere is gold and that ful greet plentee
(base) That shal departed been among vs thre
(base) But nathelees if I kan shape it so
(base) That it departed were among vs two
(base) Hadde I nat doon a freendes torn to thee
(base) That oother answerde I noot how that may be
(base) He woot that the gold is with vs tweye
(base) What shal we doon what shal we to hym seye
(base) Shal it be conseil seyde the firste shrewe
(base) And I shal telle in a wordes fewe
(base) What we shul doon and brynge it wel aboute
(base) I graunte quod that oother out of doute
(base) That by my trouthe I wol thee nat biwreye
(base) Now quod the firste thow woost wel we be tweye
(base) And two of vs shul strenger be than oon
(base) Looke whan that he is set that right anon
(base) Arys as though thow woldest with hym pleye
(base) And I shal ryue hym thurgh the sydes tweye
(base) Whil that thow strogelest with hym as in game
(base) And with thy daggere looke thow do the same
(base) And thanne shal al this gold departed be
(base) My deere freend bitwixe thee and me
(base) Thanne may we bothe oure lustes al fulfille
(base) And pleye at dees right at oure owene wille
(base) And thus acorded been thise sherewes tweye
(base) To sleen the thridde as ye han herd me seye
(base) This yongeste which that wente to the toun
(base) Ful ofte in herte he rolleth vp and doun
(base) The beautee of thise floryns newe and brighte
(base) O lord quod he if so were that I myghte
(base) Haue al this tresor to myself allone
(base) Ther is no man that lyueth vnder the trone
(base) Of god that sholde lyue so myrie as I
(base) And at the laste the feend oure enemy
(base) Putte in his thoght that he sholde poyson beye
(base) With which he myghte sleen his felawes tweye
(base) For why the feend foond hym in swich lyuynge

div.l: (base) That he hadde leue hym to sorwe brynge
(base) For this was outrely his ful entente
(base) To sleen hem bothe and neuere to repente
(base) And forth he goth no lenger wolde he tarye
(base) Into the toun vnto Apothecarye
(base) And preyed hym that he hym wolde selle
(base) Som poysoun that he myghte his rattes quelle
(base) And eek ther was a polcat in his hawe
(base) That as he seyde his capons hadde yslawe
(base) And fayn he wolde wreke hym if he myghte
(base) On vermyn that destroyed hym by nyghte
(base) The Pothecarie answerde and thow shalt haue
(base) A thyng that also god my soule saue
(base) In al this world ther is no creature
(base) That ete or dronke hath of this confiture
(base) Nat but the montaunce of a corn of whete
(base) That he ne shal his lyf anoon for lete
(base) Ye sterue he shal and that in lasse while
(base) Than thow wolt goon a paas nat but a myle
(base) The poyson is so strong and violent
(base) This cursed man hath in his hand yhent
(base) This poyson in a box and sith he ran
(base) In to the nexte Strete vnto a man
(base) And borwed hym large Botels thre
(base) And in the two his poison poured he
(base) The thridde he kepte clene for his drynke
(base) For al the nyght he shoop hym for to swynke
(base) In cariyng of the gold out of that place
(base) And whan this Riotour with sory grace
(base) Hadde filled with wyn hise grete Botels thre
(base) To hise felawes agayn repaireth he
(base) What nedeth it to sarmone of it moore
(base) For right as they hadde cast his deeth bifore
(base) Right so they han hym slayn and that anon
(base) And whan this was doon thus spak that oon
(base) Now lat vs sitte and drynke and make vs merye
(base) And afterward we wol his body berye
(base) And with that word it happed hym per cas
(base) To take the Botel ther the poyson was
(base) And drank and yaf his felawe drynke also

div.l: (base) For which anon they storuen bothe two
(base) But certes I suppose that Auycen
(base) Wroot neuere in no Canon ne in no fen
(base) Mo wonder signes of empoysonyng
(base) Than hadde thise wrecches two er hir endyng
(base) Thus ended been thise homicides two
(base) And eek the false empoysonere also
(base) O. cursed synne of alle cursednesse
(base) O. traytours homicide o wikkednesse
(base) O. glotonye luxure and hasardrye
(base) Thou blasphemour of Crist with vileynye
(base) And othes grete of vsage and of pryde
(base) Allas mankynde how may it bityde
(base) That to thy Creatour which that thee wroghte
(base) And with his precious herte blood the boghte
(base) Thow art so fals and so vnkynde allas
(base) Now goode men god foryeue yow youre trespas
(base) And ware yow fro the synne of Auarice
(base) Myn holy pardoun may yow alle warisse
(base) So that ye offre nobles or starlynges
(base) Or ellis siluer broches spones rynges
(base) Boweth youre heed vnder this holy bulle
(base) Cometh vp ye wyues offreth of youre wolle
(base) Youre name I entre here in my rolle anon
(base) In to the blisse of heuene shul ye gon
(base) I yow assoille by myn heigh power
(base) Ye that wol offre as clene and eek as cler
(base) As ye were born and lo sires thus I preche
(base) And Ihu crist that is oure soules leche
(base) So graunte yow his pardoun to receyue
(base) For that is best I wol yow nat deceyue
(base) But sires o word forgat I in my tale
(base) I haue Relikes and pardon in my male
(base) As faire as any man in Engelond
(base) Whiche were me yeuen by the Popes hond
(base) If any of yow wol of deuocioun
(base) Offren and han myn absolucioun
(base) Com forth anon and kneleth here adoun
(base) And mekely receyueth my pardoun
(base) Or ellis taketh pardoun as ye wende

div.l: (base) Al newe and fressh at euery myles ende
(base) So that ye offren alwey newe and newe
(base) Nobles or pens whiche that been goode and trewe
(base) It is an honour to euerich that is heer
(base) That ye mowe haue a suffisant pardoner
(base) Tassoille yow in contree as ye ryde
(base) For auentures whiche that may bityde
(base) Parauenture ther may falle oon or two
(base) Doun of his hors and breke his nekke atwo
(base) Looke which a seuretee is it to yow alle
(base) That I am in youre felaweship yfalle
(base) That may assoille yow bothe moore and lasse
(base) Whan that the soule shal fro the body passe
(base) I rede that oure hoost shal bigynne
(base) For he is moost envoluped in synne
(base) Com forth sire hoost and offre first anon
(base) And thow shalt kisse the Relikes euerychon
(base) Ye for a grote vnbokele anon thy purs
(base) Nay nay quod he thanne haue I Cristes curs
(base) Lat be quod he it shal nat be so thee ich
(base) Thow woldest make me kisse thyn olde breech
(base) And swere it were a Relyk of a Seint
(base) Thogh it were with thy fondement depeynt
(base) But by the croys which that Seint Eleyne foond
(base) I wold I hadde thy coylons in myn hond
(base) In stide of Relikes or of Seintuarie
(base) Lat cutte hem of I wol thee hem carie
(base) They shul be shryned in an hogges toord
(base) This pardoner answerde nat a word
(base) So wrooth he was no word ne wolde he seye
(base) Now quod oure hoost I wol no lenger pleye
(base) With thee ne with noon oother angry man
(base) But right anon the worthy knyght bigan
(base) Whan that he saugh that al the peple lough
(base) Namoore of this for it is right ynough
(base) Sire Pardoner be glad and murye of cheere
(base) And sire hoost that been to me so deere
(base) I pray yow that ye kisse the Pardoner
(base) And Pardoner I pray thee drawe thee neer
(base) And as we diden lat vs lawe and pleye

div.l: (base) Anon they kiste and ryden forth hir weye
(base) Here is ended the Pardoners tale

Here endeth the Perdoners tale
And begynneth þe Shipmannes tale
A marchant whilome dwelled at seint Denys
Þat riche was for which men hilde him wys
A wyf he hedde of excellent beaute
And compaignable and revelous was she
Which is athing þat causeth mote dispence
Than worth is al þe cheere and reverence
Þat men hem done at festes and at daunces
Suche salutacions and contenaunces
Passen as doth þe shadew vpon þe walle
But wo is him þat payen mote for alle
Þe sely housbonde algate he most paye
He mote vs cloth and he mote vs arraye
Al for his owne worshup richely
In whiche array we dauncen Iolily
And if þat he noght pay ꝓproauenture
Or ellis lest no such despence endure
But thinketh it is but wasted and yloste
Þen mote another paien for oure coste
Or lene vs golde and þat is ꝓproilous
Þis noble marchant hilde a worthi hous
For whiche he hedde alday such repaire
For his largenesse and for his wyfe was feyre
Þat wonder is but harkeneth to my tale
Amonges alle his gastes grete and smale
Þer was a monke a feire man and a bolde
I trow athritty wyntꝰer he was olde
Þat euꝰer in oon was drawyng to þat place
Þis yonge monke þat was so feire of face
Aqueynted was so with þe gode man
Sith þat hir first knawlech bygon
Þat in his hous as famuler was he
As it is possible eny frende to be
And for as mochel as þis gode man
And eke þis monke of which þat y bigan
Were bothe two yborn in o village
Þe monke him claymeth as for cosinage
And he agayn he seith not onys nay
But was as glad þer of as foule of day
For to his herte it was agrete plesance
Þus byn þey knyt with eterne alliance
And eche of hem gan other tassure
Of bretherhede while þat hir lyfe may dure
Fre was daun Iohn and manly of dispence
And in þat hous al folle of diligence
To don plesance and also grete costage
He nat for gate to yeve þe leste page
Whanne þat he come some maner honeste þyng
For which þey were as glad of his comyng
As foule is fayne whan þat þe sonne vp riseth
Na more of þis as now for it suffiseth
But so befel þis marchaunt on aday
Shape him to make rede his array
Towarde þe toun of Brugges for to fare
To bien þere aporcion of ware
For which he hath to parys sent anon
A messeger and preyed hath daun Iohn
Þat he shulde come to seint denys ⁊ pley
With him and with his wyf a day or dwey
Er he to brugges went in al wys
Þis noble Monke of which y you deuyse
Hath of his abbat as him liste licence
Be cause he was aman of high prudence
And eke an officer oute forto ride
To seen hir granges and hir barnes wyde
And vnto seint denys he cometh anon
Who was so welcome as my lorde dan Iohn
Oure dere Cosyn ful of curtesie
With him Broȝt he a Iubbe of maliuesie
And eke another ful of fyne vernage
And volatil as ay was his vsage
And þus ylete hem ete and drynke and pley
Þis marchant and þis monke aday or twey
Þe þridde day þis marchant vp ariseth
And on his nedes sadly him avyseth
And vp into his counter hous goth he
To reken with him selue wel may be
Of þilke yere how þat it with him stode
And how þat he dispended hedde his gode
And if þat he encresed were or non
His bokis and his baggis many on
He leyth byforn him on his countyngborde
Ful rich was his tresoure and his horde
For which ful fast his counterborde he shette
And eke he nolde þat no man shulde him lette
Of his acountes for þe mene tyme
And þus he sitte stille forto hit passed pryme
Daun Iohn was reson in þe morn also
And in the gardyn walked to and fro
And hath his þinges seyde ful curteysly
Þis gode wyf come walkyng pryuely
Into þe gardyn þer he walked softe
And him salueth as she hath don ofte
A mayde childe came in hir compaignye
Which as hir liste may gouerne and gye
For yet vnder þe yerde was þe mayde
O dere Cosin myn Dan Iohn she seyde
What eyleth you so rath for to ryse
Nyse qd he y ought y now suffise
Fyve oures for to slepe vppon a nyght
But it were for an olde appallad wygh
As byn þese wedded men þat lye And dare
As in a forme sit a wery hare
Were al for straught with houndes grete and smale
But deere nyce whi ben ye so pale
I trow certes þat oure gode man
Hath you laboured sith þe nyȝt bygan
Þat you were nede to resten hastily
And with þat worde he logh ful muryly
And of his owne þoght he wexe al rede
Þis faire wyf gan for to shake hir hede
And seyde þus / ye god wote al qd she
Nay cosin myn it stant natso with me
For by þat god þat yaf me soule and lyfe
In al þis Reawme of Fraunce is þer no wyfe
That lasse luste hath to þat sory pley
For y may synge allas and wellawey
Þat ywas born but to no wight qd she
Dar y not telle how it stont with me
Wherefore y thinke oute of þis londe to wende
Or ellis of my selue to make an ende
So ful am y of drede and eke of care
Þis monke by gan vpon þis wyf to stare
And seyde allas my nyce god for bede
Þat ye for eny sorowe or eny drede
For do youre self but telleth me youre grefe
ꝒProauenture y may in youre myshefe
Conseile or helpe and therfore tellith me
Al youre anoy for his shal been secre
For on my portheos y make an othe
That neuer in my lyfe for leef ne lothe
Ne shal y of no conseile you byweye
The same agayn to you y sey
By god and by þis porteos y swere
Þogh men me wolden alto peces tere
Ne shal y neuer for to gon to helle
Byweye a word of þing þat ye me telle
Nat for no Cosinage ne alliaunce
But verryly for loue and affiance
Þus byn þey sworn and here vpon þey kiste
And eche of hem tolde other what þey liste
Cosyn qd she if þat y hedde aspace
As y have non and namely in þis place
Þenne wolde ytelle alegende of mylyfe
What y haue suffred sith y was awyfe
With myn housbonde albe he youre cosin
Nay nay qd þis monke by god and by seint martyn
He is namore Cosin vnto me
Þanne is þe leef þat hangeth vpon þe tree
I clepe him so by seint Denys of fraunce
To haue þe more cause of aqueyntaunce
Of you which y have loued specially
Abouen alle wemen sikerly
Þis swere y you on my profession
Telleth youre grefe lest þat he come adoun
And hasteth you and goth a wey anon
My dere love qd she my daun Iohn
Ful lef were me þis consel forto hide
But oute it mote I may namore abide
Myn housbonde is to me þe worurst man
Þat euer was sith the worlde bigan
But sith y am a wyf it sitte not me
To tellen no wight of oure pryuete
Neither abedde ne in non other place
God shilde þat I shulde tellen for his grace
A wyf ne shal not seyn of hir housbonde
But alhonoure as y vnderstonde
Save vnto you þus moch tellen y shalle
As helpe me god he is not worth att al
In no degre the valewe of a flye
But yet my greveth most his nygardye
And wel ye wote þat wymmen naturelly
Desiren þynges vi as wel as I
Þey wolde þat hir housbondes shulde be
Hardy and wyse and therto riche and fre
And buxom vnto his wyf and fressch abedde
But by þat ilke lorde þat for vs bledde
For his honoure my self forto array
A sonday next y moste nedes pay
An hundred frankis and ellis am I lorn
Yet were me lever þat y were vnborn
Þanne me were don a shlaunder or vilanye
And if myn housbond myȝt eke espye
I were but lost and þerfore y you preye
Lene me þis some or ellis mote y deye
Daun Iohn y sey lene me þis hundred frankis
Parde y wil not fayle you my thankis
If þat ye liste to doun þat y you preye
For at a serteyne day y wol you paye
And don to you what plesance and seruyce
Þat y may don right as ye wolle deuise
And bote y do god take on me vengeaunce
As foule as euer hedde Genelyn of Fraunce
Þis gentile monke answered in þis manere
But trewly myn owne lady dere
I haue qd he on you so grete a routh
That y you swere and plyȝt you my trouth
Þat whenne youre housbonde is to flaundres fare
I wol delyver you oute of this care
For y wol brynge you an hundred frankys
And with þat worde he caught hir by the flankis
And hir embraseth herde and kiste hir ofte
Goth now youre wey qd he al stylle and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as þat ye may
For by the chilindre it is pryme of day
Goth now and be as trew as I shal be
Now ellis god forbede sir qd she
And forth he goth as Iolif as a pye
And bad the Cokes þat þey shulde hem hye
So þat me myght dyne and that anon
Vp to hir housbonde is þis wyf y gon
And knokked at þe countere boldely
Who is þer qd he / ye petir it am I
Qd she what sir how longe well ye faste
How longe tyme wol ye ryken and caste
Youres sommes and youre bokes and youre þinges
Þe deuel have part on alle suche rikenynges
I haue ynow pardee of goddes sonde
Come doun to day and lete youre bagges stonde
Ne be ye nat ashamed þat daun Iohn
Shal fastyng al þis day elonge gon
What lete vs here amasse and go dyne
Wyf qd þis man litel canstow deuyne
Þe courious besynesse þat we haue
For of vs chapmen also god me save
And by þat lorde þat cleped is seint yue
Skarsly amonges twelfe x shal þryve
Contynually lastyng vnto oure age
We may wel make chere and god visage
And dryve forth þe worlde as it may be
And kepen oure estate in priuete
Til we be dede or ellis þat we pleye
A pilgrymage or ellis gon oute of þe weye
And þerfore have y grete necessite
Vpon þis queynte wolde tauyse me
For euꝰermore we mote stonde indrede
Of hap and fortune in oure chapmanhede
To flaundres wol y go to morow at day
And come agayn as sone as euꝰer I may
For which my dere wyf y the beseche
As be to euꝰer wight buxom and meke
And forto kepe oure gode be curious
And honestly gouerne wel ouer hous
Þou hast inogh in euꝰery maner wyse
Þat to a thrifty housbonde may suffise
Þe lakketh non array ne non vitaile
Of siluer in þi purs shaltow nat faile
And with þat worde his counter dore he shitte
And doun he goth no lenger wolde he lette
But hastyly amasse was þer seyde
And spedily þe tables were y leyde
And to the dyner fast þey hem spedde
And richely þe monk this chapman fedde
And after dyner Dan Iohn soberly
Þis Chapman toke aparte priuelye
He seyde þus Cosin hit stondeth so
Þat wel y se to brugges wol ye go
God and seynt Austyn spede you and guyde
I prey you Cosin wysely þat ye ryde
Gouerneth yow also of youre diete
Attemprely and namely in þis hete
Be twixt vs two nedeth no strange fare
Fare wel cosin god shilde you fro care
And if þat eny thing by day or nyght
If it be in my power and my myȝt
þat ye me wol cōmmaunde in eny wyse
It shal be don right as ye wol deuyse
O thing er þat ye gon if it may be
I wol prey you forto lene me
An hundred frankes for a weke or twey
For certeyn bestes þat y most bye
To store with a place þat is ourys
God helpe me so y wolde it were youres
I shal not fayle suerly of my day
But for a thousande frankis amylewey
But lete þis þing be secre y you prey
For yet to nyȝt þis bestes moste y beye
And fare now wel myn owne Cosin dere
Graunt mercy of youre cost and of youre chere
Þis noble marchaunt gentilly anon
Answered and seyde o Cosyn myn dan Iohn
Now sikerly þis is a smale requeste
My golde is youres when þat it you leste
And nat only my golde but my chaffare
Take what you leste god shelde that ye spare
But o þing is ye know wel ynowe
Of chapmen þat hir money is hir plowe
We may creance while we haue aname
But goldeles forto be it is ashame
Pay it agayn whan it lith in youre ease
After my might ful fayn wold y you please
Þis hundred frankis he fette forthanon
And pryuely he toke hem to dan Iohn
No wight in al þis worlde wist of þis lone
Sauyng þis marchant and dan Iohn allone
Þey drynke and speke and rome a while and pley
Til þat dan Iohn rideth to his abbey
To morow came and forth þis marchant rideth
To flandres warde his pnꝰertice wel him gideth
Til he came into Brugges murily
Now goth þis mꝰerchant faste and bysily
Abounte his nede and bieth and creaunceth
He neither pleyeth at þe dees ne daunceth
But as a merchant shortely forto telle
He leyth his lif and þer y lete him dwelle
The sonday next þis marchant was agon
To seint denys ycomen is dan Iohn
With crowne and berde al fressch and new y shave
In al þe hous þer nas so lite aknaue
Ne no wight ellis þat he nas ful fayn
Þat my lorde dan Iohn was come agayn
And shortly to þe point right for to gon
Þis feire wif accorded with dan Iohn
Þat for his hondred frankis he shulde alnyȝt
Haue hir in his armes bolt vp right
And þis accorde ꝓprofurmed was in dede
In mirth al nyȝt abesy lyf þey lede
Tyl hit was day þat dan Ioh went his way
And bade the mayny farewel and have gode day
For non of hem ne no wight in the toun
Hath of dan Iohn right no suspecion
And forth he rideth home til his abbey
Or where him liste no more of him y sey
Þis marchant whan þat ended was þe feire
To seint denys he gan forto repeire
And with his wyfe he maketh feste and chere
And telleth hir þat chaffare is so dere
Þat nedes most he make a cheuyssance
For he was bounden in areconyssance
To pay twenty thousand Sheld anon
For which þis marchant is to parys gon
To borowe of certeyn frendes þat he hedde
A certeyn frankis and sōmme with him he ledde
And whanne þat he was comen into þe toun
For grete chere and grete affeccion
Vnto dan Iohn he goth him first to pley
Nat forto axe or borowe of him money
But forto wete and seen of his welfare
And forto tellen him of his chaffare
As frendes don when þey byn mette yfere
Dan Iohn him maketh fest and mury chere
And he him tolde agayn ful specially
How he hedde wel y boght and graciously
Þanked be god al hole his marchandise
Saue þat he most in al maner wyse
Maken a cheuessance as for þe beste
And þen he shulde byn in Ioy and rest
Dan Iohn answered certis y am fayn
Þat ye in hele ar comen hole agayn
And yf þat y were rich as haue yblisse
Of twenty thousand sheeld / sholde ys nat mysse
For ye so kyndely that other day
Lente me golde and as y kan and may
I thanke you by god and by seint Iame
But natheles y toke vnto oure dame
Youre wyf at home þe same golde agayn
Vpon youre bench she wot it wel certeyn
By certeyn tokens þat y kan you telle
Now by youre leue y may no lenger dwelle
Oure abbot wol oute of þis toun gon
And in his compaignye mot y gon
Grete wel oure dame myn ewe nyce swete
And farewel dere Cosin till we mete
Þis marchant which þat was ful ware and wyse
Creanced hath and payed eke in parys
To certeyn lombardes redy in hir honde
Þe sōmme of golde and gaue of hem his bonde
And home he goth as myry as a popingay
Ful wel he knew he stode in such array
Þat nedes most he wynne in þat viages
A thousand frankis abouen al his costages
His wif ful redy met him at þe gate
As she was wont of olde vsage algate
And al þat nyght in myrth þey besette
For he was riche and clerly oute of dette
Whan it was day þis marchant gan embrace
His wyf al newe and kist hir in hir face
And vp he goth and maketh it ful tough
Na more qd she by god ye have ynogh
And wantanly agayn with him she pleyed
Til atte þe laste þis marchaunt seide
By god qd he y am alitel wrothe
With you my wyfe al þogh it be me lothe
And wote ye whi by god as þat y gesse
Þat ye han made a maner strangenesse
By twixten me and my cosin dan Iohn
Ye sholde han warned me er I hedde gon
Þat he hedde you an hundred frankes payed
By redy token and helde him euel apayed
For þat y to him spake of cheuessance
Me semede so as by his contenance
But natheles by god oure hevyn kynge
I thoghtnot to axe of him no þinge
I prey þe wif ne do namore so
Tel me alwey er I fro þe go
If eny dettour hath in myn absence
Ipaied þe lest þorgh my necligence
I myȝt him axe a thing þat he hath payed
This wif was not aferde ne affrayed
But boldely she seide and þat anon
Marie y diffye þe fals monke dan Iohn
I kepe not of his tokons neuer adell
He toke me certeyn golde þis wote y well
What yuel þedam on his monkis snowte
For god it wote y wende withouten doute
Þat he hadde yeve it me by cause of you
To don þer with myn honoure and my prowe
For cosinage and eke for bele chere
Þat he hath hadde ful ofte tymes here
But sith y see it stont in such disioynt
I wol answere you shortly to þe poynt
Ye have mo shakkoure dettours þanne am I
For y wol pay yowe wel and redily
Fro day to day and if so be y faile
I am youre wyfe score it vpon my taile
And y shal pay as sone as euer y may
For by my trouth y have on myn arraye
And not in wast / bestowed euꝰery del
And for y have bestowed it so wel
For youre honoure for goddes sake y seye
As be not wroth but lete vs laugh and pley
Ye shal my Ioly body han to wedde
By god y wolnot pay you but in bedde
For geve it me myn owne spouse dere
Turne hiderward and maketh better chere
Þis marchant saugh þer was no remedye
And forto chide it nere but foly
Syn þat þe þing may nat amended be
Now wif he seide and y forgeue it þe
And by thi lyf ne be namore so large
Kepe bet þi gode þis yeve y the in charge
Þus endeth my tale and god vs sende
Taylyng ynow vnto oure lyves ende
¶ Here endeth þe Shypmannes tale .

l.hi:
Herken þe now the mery
wordes of the hoost .

div.l: Wel seyd by corpus dominus qd oure host
Now longe mote þou sayle by þe crost lF 168vl
Thow gentile maister gentile mariner
God yeue þe monke a thousand last quaad yer
Ha ha felawes beth ware of such a Iape
Þe monke putte in þe mannys hode an ape
And in his wyfes eke by seint Austyn
Draweth no monkes more in to youre yn
But now passe over and lete vs seke abowte
Who shal now telle firste of all þis rowte
Another tale and with þat worde he seide
As curteysly as it hedde byn amayde
My lady prioresse by youre leve
So þat y wist y shulde you nat greue
I wolde demen þat ye telle shulde
A tale next if so were þat ye wolde
Now wol ye vouch it sauf my lady dere
Gladly qd she and seyde as ye shal here

¶ Here begynneth the prohem
of the Prioresse tale .
O lorde o lorde þy name how meruelous
Is in this large worlde ysparde qd she
For nat only þi loude pꝰercious
ꝒProfourmed is by men of dignite
But by þe mouth of children þy bountee
ꝒProfourmed is for on þe brest sowkynge
Somme tyme shewen þey þyn herienge
¶ Where fore in loude as y best kan or may
Of þe and of þe white lyly floure
Which þat þe bar and is amayde alwey
To tellen astory ywolle do my laboure
Nat þat y may encressen hir honoure
For whiche hir selfe is honoure and þe rote
Of bounte next hir sone and sowles bote
¶ O moder mayde o mayde moder fre
O bussch vnbrent brennyng in Moyses sight
Þat ravesshedest downe fro the deite
Þorgh þyn homblesse þe gost þat in þe alight
Of whos vertu whanne he þy herte light
Conceyved was þe fadres sapience
Helpe me to telle it in þy reverence
¶ Lady þy bounte thi magnificence
Thi vertu and thi grete humilite
Þer may no tonge expresse in no science
For sōmme tyme lady er men prey the
Þou gost byforn of þi benignite
And getest vs the light of þi preyere
To giden vs to thi sone so dere
My konnyng is so wayk o blisful quene
Forto declare þi grete worthinesse
Þat y ne may þe wight not sustene
But as a childe of twelf month olde or lesse
Þat kan vnnethe eny worde expresse
Right so fare I and þerfore y you prey
Gydeth my songe þat I of you shal sey

¶ Here endeth the prohem . And here begynneth
the Pryores tale of Alma redemptoris mater
Ther was in asye in agrete Citee
Amonges Cristen folke in Iuerye
Sustened by alorde of þat contre
For foule vsure and lucre of vilanye
Hateful to Crist and to his companye
And thorgh þe strete men myȝt ryde and wende
For it was fre and open atte euyꝰer ende
¶ A litel scole of Cristen folke þer stode
Doun at the ferther ende in which þer were
Children an hepe ycomen of cristen blode
Þat lerned in þat scole yer by yere
Such maner doctrine as men vsed there
Þis is to seyn to syngen and to rede
As smale children don in hir childhede
¶ Amonge þis children was a weddewes sone
A litel clargeon seven yere of age
Þat day by day to scole was his wone
And eke also where as he say þe ymage
Of cristes moder hedde he in vsage
As him was taught to knele adown and seye
His Aue marie as he goth by þe weye
¶ Þis hath þis widdew hir litel sone ytaught
Oure bessed lady Cristes moder dere
To worshup ay and he forgate it noght
Fol sely childe wolle algate sone lere
But ay when y remembre on þis matere
Seint Nicholas stant euꝰer in my pꝰersēmnce
For he so yonge to crist dede reuerence
¶ Þis litel childe his litel boke lernynge
As he sate in his scole at his prymere
He Alma redemptoris herde synge
As children lernen hir Antiphonere
And as he dorst he drowe him nere and nere
And herkened ay þe wordes and þe note
Tille he þe first vers coude by rote
¶ Nat wist he what þis latyn was to seye
For he so yonge and tendre was of age
But on a day his felawe gan he praye
Texpounden him þis songe in his langage
Or telle him whi þis songe was in vsage
Þis preyed he him to construen and declare
Ful ofte tyme vpon his knees bare
¶ His felaw which þat elder was þan he
Answered him þus þis songe I have herde seye
Was made of oure blisful lady fre
Hir to salue and eke hir forto preye
To ben oure helpe and socoure when we deye
I kanne namore expounde in þis matere
I lerne songe y kanne but smale grānmere
¶ And is þis songe maked in reuerence
Of cristes moder seyde þis Innocent
Now certes y wol do my diligence
To konne it alle er cristesmasse is went
Þogh þat I for my prymer shal be shent
And shal be beten þries in an oure
I wol it konne oure lady forto honoure
¶ His felawe taught hym homwarde prevely
Fro day to day til he cowde it by rote
And þenne he songe it wel and boldely
Fro worde to worde accorded with þe note
Twyes aday it passed þorgh his þrote
To scolewarde and homward whenne he wente
On cristes moder sette was his entente
¶ As I have seide þorgh oute the Iewrye
Þis litel childe as he cam to and fro
Ful murilie wolde he synge and crye
O Alma redemptoris euꝰer mo
Þe swetnesse his herte ꝓproced so
He cannot stynt of syngyng by þe wey
Of cristes moder to hir forto prey
¶ Oure first fo þe serpent sathanas
Þat hath in Iewys herte his waspes neste
Vn swal and seyde o hebrayk peple allas
Is þis a thing to yow þat is not honeste
Þat such aboye shal walken where as him leste
In youre dispite and syngen of such sentence
Which is agayns oure lawes reuerence
¶ Fro þennes forth þe Iewes han conspired
Þis Innocent oute of þis worlde to chase
And homycide þer to han þey hired
Right in an aley atte aprevee place
And as þe childe gan þerby for to pace
Þis cursed Iewe him hent and hilde him faste
And kut his þrote and in a pyt him caste
¶ I sey þat in a wardrope þey him drewe
Wher as þis Iewes purgen hir entraille
O cursed folke of herodes al newe
What may youre yuel entente you auaille
Mordre wol oute certeyn it wol not faile
And namely þer as þe honoure of god shal sprede
Þe blood oute crieth on youre cursed dede
¶ O martir sounded to virginite
Now maistow syngen euer folowyng in on
Þe white lambe celestial qd he
Of which þe grete euangelist seint Iohn
In pathmos wrote which seith þtat þe þat gon
Byforn þis lambe and synge a song alnewe
Þat neuer flesschly womma þey ne knewe
¶ Þis pore widdewe awayteth al þat nyght
After hir litel childe and he came noght
For which as sone as it was dayes light
With face pale of drede and besy thoght
She hath at scole and ellis where hym soght
Tyl fynally she gan so ferre aspye
Þat he last was seyn in þe Iewrye
¶ With modres pite in hir brest enclosed
She goth as she were halfe oute of hir mynde
To euꝰery place where as she hath supposed
By liklyhede hir litel childe to fynde
And euer on cristes moder meke and kynde
She cried and atte last þus she wroght
Amonge þe cursed Iewes she hym southt
¶ She frayneth and she freyneth pitously
To euꝰery Iewe þat dwēmlt in þilke place
To telle hir yf hir childe wende ought forby
Þey seyde nay but ihu of his grace
Yaf in hir þoght in with a litel space
Þat in þat place after hir sone she cried
Where he was caston in a pit byside
¶ O grete god þat ꝓprofourmest þi laude
By mouth of Innocentȝ lo here þy myght
Þis gemme of chastite this Emeraude
And eke of martirdom þe Ruby bryght
Þer he with þrote ykoruen lith vp right
He Alma redemptoris gan to synge
So loude þat all þe place gan to rynge
¶ Þe Cristen folke þat þorgh þe strete wente
In comen forto wondre vpon þis þynge
And hastily þey for the prouoste sente
He kam anon withouten taryenge
And herieth crist þat is of heue kynge
And eke his moder honour of mankynde
And after þat þe Iewes lete he bynde
¶ Þis childe with pitous lamentacion
Vp taken was syngyng his songe alwey
And with honoure of grete procession
Þey carien him vnto þe next abbay
His moder sownyng by his bere lay
Vnneth myght þe peple þat was þere
Þis newe rachel bryngen fro þe bere
¶ With torment and with shameful deth echon
Þis prouost doth þis Iewes forto sterue
Þat of þis mordre wist and þat anon
He nolde no such cursednesse obserue
Evel shal he haue þat euer wol deserue
Þerfore with wilde hors he dide hem drawe
And after þat he hyng hem by þe lawe
¶ Vpon his bere ay lith þis Innocent
Byforn þe chef aute while þe masse laste
And after þat þe abbot with his couent
Han spedde hem forto burien him ful faste
And whanne þey holy water vpon him caste
Yet spake þis childe wanne spreyned was þe holy watꝰer
And songe O Alma redemptoris mater
¶ This abbot which þat was anholy man
As monkes been or ellis oght to be
Þis yonge childe to coniure he biganne
And seyd odere childe I halsen þe
In vertu of þe holy trinite
Telle me what is þe cause þat þou dost synge
Sith þat þy þrote is kutte in my semynge
¶ My throte is kutte vnto my nek bon
Seide this childe and as by wey of kynde
I shulde have dyed ye longe tyme agon
But ihu Criste as ye in bokis fynde
Wol þat his glorie last and be in mynde
And for þe worshup of his moder dere
Þat may y synge O Alma lowde and clere
¶ Þis welle of mercy Cristes moder swete
I loued al wey as after my konnynge
And whanne þat y my lyfe sholde for lete
To me she came and bade me forto synge
Þis Anteme verraily in my deynge
As ye hadde herde and whan þat y hedde songe
Me thoght she leyde agryn vpon my tonge
¶ Wherfore y singe mote certeyn
In honorur of þat blisful mayden free
Til fro my tonge ytaken be the greyn
And after þat þus seide she to me
My litel childe now wol y fecch þe
Whenne þat þe greyn is fro þis tonge ytake
Benot agast y wol þe not for sake
¶ Þis holy monke þis Abbot him mene I
His tonge oute caught and toke awey þe greyn
And he yaf vp þe gost ful softely
And whenne þis abbot hedde þis wonder seyn
His salt teris trilled doun as reyn
And gruf he fil al flat vpon þe grounde
And stille he lay as he hedde byn ybounde
¶ Þe Couent eke lay vpon þe pauement
Weping and herieng Cristes moder dere
And after þat þey rise and forth ben went
And toke awey þis martir from his bere
And in a tombe of marbulstones clere
Enclosen þey þis litel body swete
Þer he is now god leve vs forto mete
¶ O yonge hugh of lyncoln slayn also
With cursed Iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litel while y go
Prey eke for vs we sinful folke vnstable
Þat of his mercy god so merciable
On vs his grete merci multiplye
For reuerence of his moder Marye Amen
¶ Here endeth the pryoresse tale .

Beholde the
mery talking of the hoost to þe Chaucer
Whan seide was al þis miracle euꝰery man
As sobre was þat wonder was to see
Til þat oure hoste iapen þo bigon
And thenne at erst he loked vpon me
And seide þus what man artow qd he
Þou lokest as þoght þou woldest fynde an hare
For euꝰer vpon þe grounde y se the stare
¶ Approche ner and loke vp meryly
Now ware you siris and lete þis man have place
He in þe wast is shapen as wel as I
Þis were apopet in an arme tenbrace
For eny womman smal and feyre of face
He semeth eluyssh by his contenaunce
For vnto no wight doth he no daliaunce
¶ Sey now somwhat syn other folke han seyde
Telle vs atale of mirth and þat anon
Host qd he ne beth not evel apayede
For other tale certis can y non
But of a ryme y lerned longe a gon
Ye þat is gode qd he now shal we here
Sōmme deynte þing me thinketh by his chere

l.hi:
¶ Herte foloweþ Chaucers tale of Thopas
And here begynneth his tale .

div.l: Listenneth lordynges in gode entent
And y wol telle verement
Of mirth and of solas
Al of a knyght was feire and gent
In bataile and turnament
His name was sir Thopas
¶ I born he was in fer contre
In flaundres alle be yonde the se
At poperyng in þe place
¶ His fader was aman ful free
A lorde he was of þat countre
As it was goddes grace /
¶ Sir Thopas wax adoughty swayn
White was his face as payndemayn
His lippes rede as Rose
¶ His rode is like scarlet in greyn
As y you telle in gode certeyn
He hedde a semely nose /
¶ His here his berde was like safron
Þat to his Gyrdel raght adoun
His shone of Cordewane ~
¶ Of brugges were his hosen browne
His Robe was of sykl ne
Þat cost many a Iane
¶ He coude honte at wylde dere
And ryde an hawkyng for ryvere
With grete goshauke on honde ~
¶ Þer to he was agode Archere
Of wrastelyng þer nas noon his pere
Þer any Ram shulde stonde /
¶ Ful many amayde bright in bowre
Þey morned for him ꝓproamoure
Whan hēmme were bette to slape ~
¶ But he was chaste and no lechoure
But swete as is þe Bramble floure
Þat bereth the Rede hepe /
¶ And so it fil vpon a day
For soth as y you telle may
Syr Thopas wolde oute ryde ~
¶ He warth vpon his stede gray
And in honde a launce gay
A longe swerde by his syde /
¶ He pryketh þorogh a feire foreste
Þer ynne is many a wilde beste
Ye boþ bukke and hare ~
¶ And as he pryketh north and Este
I telle it you him hedde al meste
By tydde a sory kare
¶ Þer spryngen herbes grene and smale
The lycorys and the Cedewale
And many a Clowe Ielofre
¶ And notemuge to put in ale
Wheter it be most or stale
Or forto ley in Cofre
¶ Þe Briddes songe it is no nay
Þe sparehauke and þe papin Iay
Þat Ioy it was to here
¶ Þe threstelkok made eke his lay
Þe wodedove vpon the spray
She songe ful loude and clere
¶ Sir Thopas fylle in love longynge
Al whanne he herde þe þrestel synge
And pryked as he were wode
¶ His feire stede in his prykyng
So swatte þat ght him wryng
His sides were al blo
¶ Sir Thopas eke so wery was
For prykyng on þe softe gras
So fers was his Corage
¶ Þat doun he layde him in þe place
To make his stede some solas
And yaf him gode forage
¶ O seint marie benedicite
What eyleth þis love at me
To bynde me so sore
¶ Me dremed al þis nyȝt ꝑperdee
An Elfe quene shal my lemmān be
And slepe vnder my gore
¶ An Elfe quene wol y haue y wys
For in þis worlde no womman is
Worthi to ben my make
in town
¶ Al other wymmen y forsake
And to an Elfe quene y me take
By dale and eke by down
¶ Into his sadel he clambe anon
And pryketh ouer stile and ston
An Elfe quene forto espie
¶ Til he so longe hedde riden and gon
Þat he found in apryve won
Þe contre of feirye .
So wilde
For in þat contre was
neyther man wyf ne childe
¶ Tyl þat þer came a grete geaunt
His name was sir malefaunt
A ꝑperilous man of dede
¶ He childe by turmagaunt
But if þou pike oute of myn haunt
Anon y sle þi stede .
With mace
¶ Here is þe quene of feire
With harpe and pipe and symphonye
Dwellyng in þis place
¶ Þe childe seyde also mote y the
To morowe wol y mete þe
Whan I haue myn Armowre
¶ And yet y hope þar ma fey
Þat þou shalte with þis lancegay
Abyen it ful sowre .
þi mawe
¶ Shal y ꝑpercen yf y may
Er it be fully pryme of day
For here shaltow be slawe
¶ Sir Thopas drowe abak ful faste
Þis geaunt at him stones caste
Out of a fel staf slynge
¶ But faire escaped childe Thopas
And al it was þorgh goddes garace
And þorgh his feire beryng
¶ Yet lesteth lordes to my tale
Murier þanne þe nyghtyngale
I wol you rowne
¶ How sir Thopas with sides smale
Prikyng ouer hil and dale
I come agayn to towne
¶ His murye men commaunded he
To maken him both game and gle
For nedes most he fight
With a geant with hedes þre
For ꝓproamoure and Iolite
Of oon þat shon ful bright
¶ Do come he seide my mynstrales
And gestoures for to tellen tales
Anon in myn Amyng
¶ Of Romaunce þat byn reales
Of popes and of Cardinales
And eke of love lykyng
¶ Þey fette him firste swete wyn
And mete eke in a Maselyn
And Rial spicerie
¶ Of gyngebrede þat was ful fyne
And licorous and eke comyn
With sigour þat is trie
¶ He dede next his white leer
Of cloþ of lake fyn and clere
A brech and eke a sherte
¶ And next his shorte an Aketon
And over þat an habergeon
For ꝑpercyng of his harte
¶ And ouer þat an haubryk

Here the hoost stynteth Chaucer of hys tale of

div.l: Namore of þis for goddes dignite
Qd oure host for þu makest me
So wery of þi very lewdnesse
Þat also wisly god my soule blisse
Myn erys aken of þi drasty speche lF 175rl
Now such a ryme the deuel y be teche
Þis may wel be ryme dogerel qd he
Why so qd I whi woltow lette me
More of my tale þanne another man
Syn þat it is þebest ryme y kanne
By god qd he for pleynly at o worde
Þis drasty rymyng is not worth a torde
Þou dost noghe ellis but dispendist tyme
Sir at oworde þu shalt no lenger ryme
Lette se wher þou kanste telle aught in geste
Or telle in prose sūnwhat at þe leste
In which þer be sūnme mirth or some doctrine
Gladly qd I be goddes swete pyne
I wol you telle that is no lose
That aught to like you as I suppose
Or ellis certis ye be to daungerous
It is a moral tale vertuous
Al be it tolde sūn tyme in sundry wyse
Of sundry folke as I shal you deuyse
As þus ye wote þat euꝰery euangeliste
Þat telleth vs þe peyn of ihūn criste
Ne sith not al þing as his felawe doth
But natheles hir sentence is al soth
Al accorden as in hir sentence
Al be þer in hir tellyng difference
For sōmme of hem seyn more and sōmme seyn lesse
When þey his pitous passiou expresse
I mene of merke mathew luke and Iohn
But douteles hir sentence is al oon
Þerfore lordynges y you al beseche
If þat ye þinke y varie as in my speche
As þus þogh þat y telle somwhat more
Of prouerbs þan ye han herde byfore
Comprehended in this litel tretis here
To enforcen with theffecte of my matere
And þogh y not þe same wordes sey
As ye han herde yet to you alle y prey
Blameth me not for as in my sentence
Shul ye nowher fynden difference
For the sentence of þis tretis lite lF 175vl
After þe whiche þis myry tale y write
And þerfore herkneth what y shal you sey
And lete me tellen as my tale y prey
Here endeth Chaucers tale .
